review_preview: I've been to Marina Ventura four times over the past several months, usually when I have friends or family visiting and they want an authentic paella experience in Madrid. I had three lovely visits in the past, and I even left a very positive review...
review_full: I've been to Marina Ventura four times over the past several months, usually when I have friends or family visiting and they want an authentic paella experience in Madrid. I had three lovely visits in the past, and I even left a very positive review on TripAdvisor in May. However, when I visited in late May, we ordered the paella de mariscos. I got absolutely horrible food poisoning and threw up for almost a whole day, causing me to miss work. My friend who was flying back to the U.S. also got food poisoning and had a miserable flight back home. I know that nothing else I'd eaten in the day before could have caused this food poisoning. The restaurant emailed me asking for general feedback after my meal and I explained what happened and never heard anything back from them. I found the lack of response very unprofessional. I had really enjoyed my previous visits to this restaurant, but I unfortunately will not be returning now.

title_review: Be very careful with the prices!
review_preview: I went today 5/9/2019 with my fiancé and a friend. I ordered cheese and bread, Octopus, Shrimp and Paella. The menu said Paella for "18 euros" and "minimum 2 people." So we thought to order 1 paella to share among us 3. But at the...
review_full: I went today 5/9/2019 with my fiancé and a friend. I ordered cheese and bread, Octopus, Shrimp and Paella. The menu said Paella for "18 euros" and "minimum 2 people." So we thought to order 1 paella to share among us 3. But at the end, they charged us for 3 paellas claiming the price of 18 euro was PER CUSTOMER. This was not clear on the menu. When we told our waiter we wanted 1 paella for us, he brought three orders of paella in one big paella pan, so 3 x18= 54 euros. Now, I have eaten at expensive restaurants and cheap places, but this is by far the shadiest experience I've ever had. He knew we wanted one dish for 18 euros to share with 3 people but instead he brought 3 orders worth to make more profit. The funny part was that I speak and read perfect Spanish and when I talked to him he told me "you should read the menu very carefully". If you're not trying to scam people, why would you put something like that "in fine print"? I would not recommend this restaurant. Food was average - not bad, just plain food.  This is my first review having used TripAdvisor for years and I only wrote it because they should be more professional and explain their shady and confusing menu.

review_preview: And not a favorable one. When we arrived, I was wearing a dark blazer and slacks and they asked me to wear a tie. (My wife looked great and passed inspection.) But I was secretly pleased. A demanding classicism, I thought. How cool. But it...
review_full: And not a favorable one. When we arrived, I was wearing a dark blazer and slacks and they asked me to wear a tie. (My wife looked great and passed inspection.) But I was secretly pleased. A demanding classicism, I thought. How cool. But it was not to be. The restaurant is leather banquets and linen tablecloths. Nice but unimaginative place settings. Modest art. An older (largely +50) clientele. So we fit right in. Service throughout was polite but incredibly impersonal and in one case, bad. More on that to come.  The amuse bouche was embarrassing. nothing more than a potato puff.  My wife's prawn salad was tasteless and covered in mayonnaise. Beyond dull. My ravioli with mushrooms and a (very) little fois gras in a cream sauce was actually tasty. Traditional, but refreshing in that regard. I ordered baby lamb rare. My wife had the roast chicken. When my lamb arrived, it was a dull gray. I remarked on that and was told that it was baby lamb and should never be served rare. That may be so, but someone could have said that to me. The lamb was decent, but no one on the wait staff ever came back to inquire if I was satisfied. It bordered on rude. My wife's chicken was fine, but nothing that either of us couldn't have roasted in a heartbeat.  But it was the vegetables that accompanied the main courses that were totally unacceptable: cold, overcooked, tasteless. Frankly, embarrassing if they had come from an institutional buffet. The desserts were so poorly translated on the menu (no one in the restaurant spoke much English) that we ordered ice cream to be safe. Again, okay but so unimaginatively presented.  If this place was in France it would be roadkill. After two lovely meals in Madrid, we were really looking forward to Zalacain. At the prices, we figured it would be special. It was so NOT. Consider yourselves warned!

title_review: An expensive disappointment - I will not give it a second chance
review_preview: I went to Zalacain for dinner with my wife in our wedding anniversary, expecting a formal atmosphere and excellent food. There was a somewhat formal atmosphere, spoiled by the executive with a young woman in an excessively revealing dress. We had dinner in the main...
review_full: I went to Zalacain for dinner with my wife in our wedding anniversary, expecting a formal atmosphere and excellent food. There was a somewhat formal atmosphere, spoiled by the executive with a young woman in an excessively revealing dress. We had dinner in the main hall, with some very bad modern paintings hanging on the walls and a very tacky table centerpiece (quite hideous: a silver basket with apples and a green plant emerging from it) that we quickly set aside.  The Chefs de Salle had the looks of old hands of the Franco regime and were quite rude in making comments between themselves and with the waiters regarding our choice of menu and wine, even after we told them we understood Spanish quite well. I was surprised by the fact that the menu they offered my wife included prices (something I did not expect from such a formal restaurant). In contrast, the sommelier as well as the waiters were professional and efficient. The real disappointment was the food. Excellent ingredients spoiled by bad concepts and a quality of execution that was far bellow par for such a restaurant. We started with the lobster salad. The lobster was overcooked, giving it a rubbery texture. It was accompanied by a heavy sauce that completely overwhelmed the shelfish: not the Sherry vinegar dressing advertised in the menu... It made me ask: what's the point? In a few bites I tasted the glory of the lobster, but too little and only after trying to clean the sauce off! For the entrees we chose fish. I had the grouper ("Mero a la plancha com emulsion de vinagreta de marisco"). The fish was excellent but the dish was badly executed: the top was beautifully grilled but was simply too salty. As for the inner part of the fish, it basically had no salt at all. As for the sauce, It was bland and added nothing to the dish.  My wife had the sole fillets with soya and Kenyan bean sauce. Not the best concept: the sole was overcooked (she didn't eat more than a quarter of the portion), and the sauce was just too heavy for the fish.  Wondering what they couldn't ruin, we finished with a raspberry sorbet. That was excellent, as were the sweets served with coffee. All in all, it may impress turists from other parts of the world with money to spend, but it definitely does not live up to the standard or to the reviews I read here at Trip Advisor. We will not return. Michelin should really improve their standards: one star? Not in my book!

title_review: I COULD NOT ASK FOR MORE.
review_preview: This is the first time I am writing a review in TripAdvisor but I guess It's because the place, the food and the customer service deserve it big time. I am passionate about food and I also work in the food  service in London and...
review_full: This is the first time I am writing a review in TripAdvisor but I guess It's because the place, the food and the customer service deserve it big time. I am passionate about food and I also work in the food service in London and when accidentally I found myself sat in this bar I once again re-assure myself the God exists. Ylenia is a fantastic Italian young lady (I think she owns the place with her husband) with lot of enthusiasm, very smiley, attentive to your needs and with an accurate knowledge of all the products, ingredients, brands, make of the menu (she would even give you the recipe if you ask). They have several kinds of fresh pasta which can be matched with different sauces that make your mouth water. Well, I decided to have ravioli made with goat cheese and figs and also because I am not really friend with diets and I love carbohydrates I opt for another portion of ravioli but this time with burrata. OMG. DELICIOUS. I did not have anymore room on my belly but I was tempted in having also ravioli with artichokes or ricotta cheese and spinach or cheese and pears etc... I also had the pleasure to meet and chat with Chef Boja - very popular in Spain - looks after every single dish before comes out from the kitchen. Please don't you dare to leave without having had a Tiramisu - this is special. Great perfumes, aromas and atmosphere. It is a must go place.  I hope you will soon launch a Pasta Mito in London. Forza Italia.

review_preview: Get here early to get one of the few tables. It opens at 8 and is full by 8:30. The tapas are fantastic. We started with the excellent pork on carmelized onions on toast, then the mains of squid wrapped in ham with a mousse...
review_full: Get here early to get one of the few tables. It opens at 8 and is full by 8:30. The tapas are fantastic. We started with the excellent pork on carmelized onions on toast, then the mains of squid wrapped in ham with a mousse of ink and the stewed ox tail and potato. The squid dish was large enough to serve four people. The ox tail dish, which was touted in the French guide Le Routard, was fabulous. The staff spoke some English, but more importantly the menu was in English, French, Italian and Spanish, which is a real help for some of the more obscure tapas dishes. The wine selection was very good and even the lowest priced red was quite good. Staff were friendly and professional. The only downsides to this place are that it is modern and doesn't have that traditional tapas bar look, there are too few tables, and the wooden seats are uncomfortable. But the food makes up for any discomfort. The modern music was a little annoying at first, but as soon as the place filled up around 8:30, you could no longer hear it.

title_review: A good lunch for a price
review_preview: We dined here for lunch one day while browsing Madrid. We were looking for paella and this place was open. The interior is nicely decorated and we found the staff polite and attentive.Their wine is good, as is the paella mariscos. Along with paella,...
review_full: We dined here for lunch one day while browsing Madrid. We were looking for paella and this place was open. The interior is nicely decorated and we found the staff polite and attentive. Their wine is good, as is the paella mariscos. Along with paella, we ordered the argentinian steak, rare, and I wasn't very happy with it. I found it lacked taste and it was nearly cold when it reached our table. Also, the patatas fritas that come with the steak are below par. Generally, if you are nearby and want to grab something to eat, this place is fine. The food won't be top quality, it won't be something you'll remember, but it's fine for a meal. The offputting factor should be the price. Two paellas, a steak and wine for three people comes to around 86 euros. We ate in other places in Barcelona, Madrid, Granada and Malaga, had a better experience and for less money so take that into account.

title_review: Do yourself a favour and reserve a table at Casa Lucas

review_full: Three of us, on a recent night out in Madrid, had the good fortune to eat here. A local advised us to book a table in advance and this is advice that I would pass along to anyone interested in securing a table at Casa Lucas as the dining area is limited. The food and the service were consistently top-notch. Two of the gentlemen working in the dining room spoke perfect English and the menu is available in a number of languages. Standout menu items that we sampled were the salad with scallops, the octopus carpaccio and the stewed oxtail. I would not hesitate to recommend this restaurant and I will happily return when next in Madrid. Thank you.

review_preview: We stopped in for an early lunch (1pm), during our latest stay in Madrid and has two very memorable dishes. We started with some lovely, traditional mushroom croquettes - creamy, and tasty balls of deep fried goodness.  Next came one if the memorable dishes -...
review_full: We stopped in for an early lunch (1pm), during our latest stay in Madrid and has two very memorable dishes.  We started with some lovely, traditional mushroom croquettes - creamy, and tasty balls of deep fried goodness. Next came one if the memorable dishes - black pudding (blood sausage) on toast. Wow. This was some of the best blood sausage we have had. Next came the second memorable dish - calamari bundles with bacon in a squid ink sauce. Very unique, and cooked to perfection. The taste was something we have never had before, salty and creamy with tender calamri and an interesting visual. Service was quick, very helpful with the menu and attentive when needed. The space has a nice bar, but it is cramped and be prepared for a wait during peak times as it's very popular.

The food was worth waiting for... We had such a lovely time!! And by the time we were about to leave, the owner approached us and chatted with us for a while. Amazing staff (one of the best experiences we have had with restaurant staff) and the most lovely owner. We highly recommend this place... We hope to come back next time we're in Madrid.

review_preview: We went to this restaurant based on its high google review. It has a modern restaurant look. The rice is good. Service is not so good. The waitress didn't speak any English. It's very hard to communicate. After we ordered, they put two cold breads...
review_full: We went to this restaurant based on its high google review. It has a modern restaurant look. The rice is good. Service is not so good. The waitress didn't speak any English. It's very hard to communicate. After we ordered, they put two cold breads on our plate (each costs 1.9 €) without even asking if we wanted it.  What really motivates me to write this review is a repeated charge in our bill. The menu clearly indicates that 10% VAT(value added tax) is included in the price. However, when we got the bill, another 10% of IVA/VAT was added, with no explanation. Because of language barrier, we cannot get an answer but have to pay the bill (The waitress just waved her hand and said no English). When we dine in neighborhood restaurants, 10% VAT is also included in menu price, and no other unexpected price is added at the total bill.  If I am not mistaken, we are charged TWICE on sales tax, 20% of total value. I'm not happy with this dishonest hidden charge. Tourists, like us, be aware!

title_review: Tasty authentic tapas in local setting
review_preview: We were looking for a local tapas experience before our reservations for a flamenco show nearby at the Corral de la Moreria. It worked out perfectly. We ordered a dry sherry and a vermouth a la Madridelenos along with an order of Madrid tapas, which...

We ordered a dry sherry and a vermouth a la Madridelenos along with an order of Madrid tapas, which was a caliente tasty chopped mushroom mixture. We arrived at about 8:15, just in time to get a seat at the bar. It filled up quickly after that with mostly local young people. We moved on to another "recommended" tapas bar that was very disappointing (avoid El Viajero if you are there for the food) compared to the food and atmosphere of Casa Lucas.

review_preview: Although there are more traditional “ arrocerias “ in Madrid, Marina Ventura excels at both Cuisine and Service. The ambiance of the restaurant is modern, simple and with a homey feeling. All the waiters have been working there for a long time now, and the...
review_full: Although there are more traditional “ arrocerias “ in Madrid, Marina Ventura excels at both Cuisine and Service. The ambiance of the restaurant is modern, simple and with a homey feeling. All the waiters have been working there for a long time now, and the menu remains very much the same. There are 3 types of Rice served at Marina Ventura: Dry Rice, also known as Paella; Meloso Rice (quite moist), and Caldoso Rice (soupy seafood rice served in a cauldron). We have tried all three types of rice and cant really say which is one is best than the other. There are also many other items in the menu, but when in Spain, eating their rice cooking is a must. Prices are moderate and wine selection is outstanding, with moderate prices too. Have been there several times and it never disappoints.

title_review: Wonderful old lady still struttin' her stuff
review_preview: Had a wonderful dinner of classic haute cuisine last week. No froth, no odd pairings just simply wonderful food, service and wine. Reminded me of La Grenouille in New York, or any one of the Michelin restaurants of the 90's. They may have lost a...
review_full: Had a wonderful dinner of classic haute cuisine last week. No froth, no odd pairings just simply wonderful food, service and wine. Reminded me of La Grenouille in New York, or any one of the Michelin restaurants of the 90's. They may have lost a couple of stars, but I suspect more to the whims of the current food scene rather than their offerings. For four of us best starters were the salmon and an unbelievable delicious poached octopus. Mains included a small steak filets, venisons and a capon. All beautifully cooked and presented. Dessert was chocolate and being in Madrid we of course accompanied it with a terrific rioja recommended by the sommelier. Terrific fun experience.

title_review: A Far Cry from the old Zalacain
review_preview: This was a traditional special event place for the family and high expectations for the newly renovated place.  Unfortunately, it really did not live up to them.  It has parted away from the traditional and tried to move to a modern look, but has failed...
review_full: This was a traditional special event place for the family and high expectations for the newly renovated place. Unfortunately, it really did not live up to them. It has parted away from the traditional and tried to move to a modern look, but has failed to achieve that.  On the food side (forgot to take pictures again), one can say it is decent but does not have that extra touch that it did before. The service has come done tremendously and they seem to be lost in what they are doing. Plates going to the wrong person, the appetizers sitting for ten minutes on the serving table beside our table, water refills are not done periodically, etc.... The desserts as well were very mediocre.  I must say that we were a bit disapointed with experience, especially when accustomed to the old Zalacain. I hope that it is just an issue with starting up again and getting the rhythm, but there is always something to say about tradition and keeping with tradition.

review_preview: Zalacain is an elegant formal restaurant offering diners the chance to experience old world charm, from flawless impeccable service to an haute cuisine menu of classical Spanish dishes.  There are no gastronomical gimmicks at Zalacain.  It’s traditional cooking using seasonal ingredients where you can easily...
review_full: Zalacain is an elegant formal restaurant offering diners the chance to experience old world charm, from flawless impeccable service to an haute cuisine menu of classical Spanish dishes.  There are no gastronomical gimmicks at Zalacain. It’s traditional cooking using seasonal ingredients where you can easily over indulge as we did. As our Spanish hosts had been there several times, they ordered a variety appetizers for the table from goose liver pate with quince jam to clams in a bean sauce with quail eggs. Our host insisted we try the minced pigs trotters that were surprisingly superb. The bread is the one thing that was disappointing as we felt it should have been freshly baked.  The main courses did not disappoint as each of our party ordered a different main course ranging from a beautiful, though heavy, stew of red-legged partridge with chickpeas, steamed sea bass, beef steak in red wine, sirloin with fresh goose liver, and a steak tartar that had the perfect level of spice. All delicious.  To finish our meal we had some perfectly made paper thin traditional Almond roof tiles and mignardises, complemented with a sexy sweet wine, Alvear PX 1927, with beautiful roasted tones. The wine list is extremely large that one is better off relying on the expertise of sommelier, Raul Revilla, who is very willing to share his extensive knowledge. Though expensive, it is worth going to Zalacain to experience it’s old world charm and classical dishes.

title_review: Excellent fish restaurant 50m away from La Puerta de Alcalá
review_preview: We went there recently for a dinner with friends ... The expectations were quite high. Some of us already knew this restaurant, not myself. I can tell you that it was spectacular in terms of food, atmosphere, etc. The price was a little bit high,...
review_full: We went there recently for a dinner with friends ... The expectations were quite high. Some of us already knew this restaurant, not myself. I can tell you that it was spectacular in terms of food, atmosphere, etc. The price was a little bit high, probably, but the quality of the food deserves it. The service was very attentive, for us it wasn't slow at all. Special thanks to José Ynglada: Olé maestro! Your breafing at the beginning of the dinner captivated us! We want for tomates (even in late winter!), alcachofas (a must), sardina ahumada (great discovery), pulpo a la gallega (we expected a little bit more) and then different dishes of tuna fish. I would recommend dados de atún picante, tiraditos de atún and morillo de atún a la brasa. It's also highly recommendable to finish with a dessert, just to try it, go for tarta fina de manzana. One of the best I've ever tried. All in all, very nice restaurant, service very attentive, extremely good food, great José Ynglada and from time to time I guess all of us can afford a restaurant like this one. Just a "but", it was a bit noisy (Friday evening) ... Congratulations Arahy, keep going!!

review_preview: This is a very upmarket and tastefully decorated restaurant.  Located just off Puerta Alcala (end of Calle Serrano) so by default the clientele will be rather exclusive and well well dressed.  They have a menu that consists of two columns all for 30 euros.  Pick...
review_full: This is a very upmarket and tastefully decorated restaurant. Located just off Puerta Alcala (end of Calle Serrano) so by default the clientele will be rather exclusive and well well dressed. They have a menu that consists of two columns all for 30 euros. Pick a starter from the left side and pick a main from the right side. Tip: We asked the waitress if we could share them, so they put them all in the middle and they provided us with small plates and each one of us had a taste of each others starter. The mains were individual. The food was excellent. Everything was delicately prepared. The dishes were rather unique. Exceptional starters included the boleitus with quail egg, and alacachofas a la brasa. One that day there were several tuna options (tiradito de atun, dados de atun rojo) very nice. The seabass ceviche had a twist but tasted very authentic as was the butterfish. All washed down with copita de mango and chocolate coulant (fondant). Fantastic lunch.

One dish was a big and thick slice tomatoe with oil and that was just amazing. The taste was just like a sun warm freshly picked tomatoe in Italy but with a crisper texture. Serrano ham and croquettes etc. was really good and to that a fresh and good wine. For main course we got a sirloin steak cooked to perfection. Staff is active and attentive, arriving well timed to the table for refill of glasses. Professional, but would benefit from being slightly more personal according to me. It is expensive, so with a slightly lower price level it would be world class. I would go here again if I wanted to give someone a treat.

title_review: Amazing experience, delicious and creative food
review_preview: We went to Bahia Taberna on the suggestion of a friend. It was a bit far from our hotel but decided to take a taxi and go...turned out to be a great decision. We are all vegetarians and had specified it while making a reservation,...
review_full: We went to Bahia Taberna on the suggestion of a friend. It was a bit far from our hotel but decided to take a taxi and go...turned out to be a great decision. We are all vegetarians and had specified it while making a reservation, they were happy to accommodate. The menu was very simple, all we had to do was decide how many courses, everything else was left to the chef, and with good reason. Every dish tasted fresh, delicious and had a modern spin to it. It was all created for us rather than modify a meat dish, which is what many other restaurants tend to do. The "carpaccio of zucchini" was memorable. The desserts were fantastic. The "choccomisu" was a delicious take on Tiramisu and their cheesecake redefined what a cheese cake ought to be. Not a single mediocre dish. Above all , the service was friendly, hospitable and attentive. All of them came across as enjoying what they do, cared about us like we were a part of the family and made it a truly enjoyable experience. Prices were reasonable and it was an unforgettable experience. We will go there anytime we are in Madrid. Caution - the place is small, the dining area had about 8 tables, all fully booked, and the bar area in front is packed with locals and visitors - better to reserve in advance.

title_review: Very interesting place for modernized tapas
review_preview: I visit this place every time I go to Madrid.It is not located in the city center, but it worths going out of the Madrilonian hectic traffic and tourists traps for a while and know a bit of the surroundings of the city.The...
review_full: I visit this place every time I go to Madrid. It is not located in the city center, but it worths going out of the Madrilonian hectic traffic and tourists traps for a while and know a bit of the surroundings of the city. The place started as a very small tavern several years ago and grew to its current size, still moderately small and without losing a piece of its quality. The tavern is divided in two spaces, the bar and tavern (where you can eat tapas) and a small restaurant (with more elaborated food) just in front of the kitchen. The food is excellent, a mix between the best traditional madrilonian tapas and the creativity of Bahia chefs (including Italian heritage), which makes it a delicious combination. Not to miss the "pizza de chipirones" (squid pizza) or a slightly truffeled-mashed potato with a low-temperature boiled egg (just delicious). These are my favourites, and I ask them every time I go. The quality of food is very good, and the chefs introduce new dishes every once in a while. All combined with a good selection of wines and beers and possibility of cocktails before or after de meal.  The staff is friendly and knows about wines that maridate well with the food. Best of all, the prizes are quite low, particularly if you compare them with other restaurants or taverns in the city center.  It is better to book in advance if you want to eat in the restaurant. Otherwise, staying in the bar area is fun. Sundays can be a bit busier, because of the traditional madrilonian aperitivo, which is quite an experience!

review_preview: We arrived at the restaurant at 8.30 and it was empty but this of course is because Spanish people tend to eat late, whereas we English like to start eating by 8.30! Nevertheless the staff were very welcoming and saw to it that we had...
review_full: We arrived at the restaurant at 8.30 and it was empty but this of course is because Spanish people tend to eat late, whereas we English like to start eating by 8.30! Nevertheless the staff were very welcoming and saw to it that we had everything we wanted.  My starter of ham hoc croquettes were absolutely delicious and my husband had smoked salmon which he too said was delicious. I then had hake with mashed potatoes which has to be one of the best piece of fish I've ever had in any restaurant. Cooked to perfection. My final course was strudel with ice cream which also was fabulous. By the time we had finished our meal the restaurant was buzzing and had a fantastic atmosphere!  Would thoroughly recommend this restaurant, although I would suggest arriving about 9/9.30 if you don't mind eating late, and do book because it gets very busy.

title_review: A negative experience although very good tapas
review_preview: The food offer is of good quality and the tapas menu is originat. But we have been suprised by the lack of professionalism and customer experience! We have requested a table for 4 at the bar and we were given one. 2 of us were...
review_full: The food offer is of good quality and the tapas menu is originat. But we have been suprised by the lack of professionalism and customer experience!  We have requested a table for 4 at the bar and we were given one. 2 of us were already there; the 2 others were joining 20minutes later. In the meantime, we ordered 2 drinks to start with and wanted to check the tapas manu at our ease. We completed our order with 2 other drinks 15 minutes later. This told, we were surprised to be put so much pressure on to order our food! After 20min someone from the bar came to our table, telling us that we need to hurry, that they cannot keep a table like this waiting such a long time and that if the two others don't join immediately, we need to do something. Given the fact that we ordered drinks and were consuming their products at that table, and that I consider having the right to take 20min before jumping to food selection, I had a very negative customer experience. The bill of more than 100€ for 4 people in a tapas bar is fully justified with a positive customer experience. But definitely not with such a bad treatment.

The award winning "calamari sandwich" was definitely 20 notches above anything else I have seen in Madrid. Then came the lamb and steak tartar. We added on the prawn dish which is not to be missed! I am so glad we still have 4 more days in Madrid so I can go again!!

title_review: Sensational -  Warrants 6 Stars if Possible.  Don´t Be Put Off by Location
review_preview: This incredible restaurant is in the most unlikely location, marooned in a soulless office park near Barajas airport.  But fear not, it is easily accessible by Metro (Barajas station) and one bus in a southward direction.  I walked from my pre-flight hotel in downtown Barajas....
review_full: This incredible restaurant is in the most unlikely location, marooned in a soulless office park near Barajas airport. But fear not, it is easily accessible by Metro (Barajas station) and one bus in a southward direction. I walked from my pre-flight hotel in downtown Barajas. On to the meal. As others did, I ordered the tasting menu and shared a liking of seafood with waiter Miguel, who speaks excellent English. What ensued was a feast of 8-10 small- and medium-sized dishes (I lost count in my bliss.), each beautifully presented, each a wonderful melange of tastes. I have never had a meal like this.  I was not initially aware of this, but the person bringing the food to the table and explaining it in great detail was the chef and owner himself, Daniel Vangoni. He is very approachable, speaks excellent English, and seems to get great enjoyment performing anonymously -- no toque for this chef -- to the delight of his clients.  It has been said by others, but I found this the best restaurant during my week´s stay in Madrid, and possibly in my life. That it cost less than 50 euros, including 3 glasses of wine, makes it a remarkable value as well.  Please do yourself a favor and make the surprising easy trek to this gem of a restaurant. And watch out for Chef Vangoni. Fame surely awaits him.

title_review: Way off the city center. Nice neighborhood. Great local atmosphere. Michelin star dishes.
review_preview: Since I run a tapas tour in Madrid I felt obliged to pay a visit to Bahia Taberna. This bar demands more than one visit to be fully enjoyed. This is due to the fact that their communication is not the best. I needed to...
review_full: Since I run a tapas tour in Madrid I felt obliged to pay a visit to Bahia Taberna. This bar demands more than one visit to be fully enjoyed. This is due to the fact that their communication is not the best. I needed to phone them to find their working hours and their website did not give me much of and idea of what they offer. We had the tasting menu which is impossible to recommend because it is always changing in price and dishes. They have a written menu of "pintxos" and "raciones" and there is also a blackboard with seasonal dishes. For what is worth, I was not impressed by their: Brussels sprout (Col de Bruselas) Ox tails (rabo de toro) Foie gras But I was truly blown away by their: Baby squid pizza----> 5 Euros--> great value, unforgettable dish, deserves a Michelin star  Grouper dish Chocolate, orange, salt and oil dessert If you are attending a trade fair in Madrid this is the restaurant to visit since it is very close to IFEMA.

review_preview: We have eaten at thousands of restaurants around the world over the past sixty years and only a few remain truly memorable. Our dining at Bahia Taberna will join that select group. Specifically, the restaurant is divided into two parts.The front area with the bar...
review_full: We have eaten at thousands of restaurants around the world over the past sixty years and only a few remain truly memorable. Our dining at Bahia Taberna will join that select group. Specifically, the restaurant is divided into two parts.The front area with the bar is more for typical drinking and tapas at tables. The back room is "white table cloth" primarily for full dinners, although they too are build around tapas. Most diners were savoring the "tasting menu" which consists of perhaps eight consecutive small portions which are updated frequently by the chef-owner. These are not the strange "vertical structures" that some chefs are so proud of and are mysteries to most diners, but are remarkably creative and absolutely delicious. You can order off of the full menu, but go with the best and order the tasting menu. The server told us that whenever we felt that we had enough, he could stop the flow. But we never did and shared both of the available deserts.  Service is excellent and servers very knowlegeble. The open kitchen showed a very active chef who somehow had time to visit each table. Considering the fine dining and an unusual amount of wine that we both enjoyed, the price was also remarkably reasonable. As Michelin might say, Bahia Taberna is "worth a special trip."

title_review: well worth the trip. Coeliac friendly
review_preview: We almost didn't bother trekking out to Bahia (Google maps exaggeratedly suggested it was an hour from Atoches - it wasn't) so glad we did.  I have coeliac disease which means I cannot have gluten, my mum who I was with doesn't.  The chef came...
review_full: We almost didn't bother trekking out to Bahia (Google maps exaggeratedly suggested it was an hour from Atoches - it wasn't) so glad we did. I have coeliac disease which means I cannot have gluten, my mum who I was with doesn't. The chef came over and told us he would create a tasting menu for us and I would have different options to make sure it was gluten free. He double checked what we did and didn't like. The restaurant area is in the back of a small bar, it only has around 6 or 7 tables and you can see into the kitchen. At first the bar area seemed more appealing atmosphere wise but as the restaurant filled up it got better. The food was wonderful - even the onions and brussel sprout appetisers were great! We had around 6 courses including scallop with bacon, courgette stuffed with gorgonzola and shrimp, egg with truffle, tuna tartare etc etc. This isn't traditional Spanish cuisine but the meal was varied, well balanced and surprising. The staff were extremely warm and accommodating. For the quality of the food the price was very good - around 70 euros a head with a bottle of wine and a sherry. A must visit in Madrid.

title_review: Hands down best restaurant in Madrid
review_preview: Serendipity is the word. On a rainy night, I had to attend a business dinner. "Business as usual" I thought. So in an unlikely night, in an unlikely location close to the airport, I discovered the best restaurant in Madrid. I still can't believe that...
review_full: Serendipity is the word. On a rainy night, I had to attend a business dinner. "Business as usual" I thought. So in an unlikely night, in an unlikely location close to the airport, I discovered the best restaurant in Madrid. I still can't believe that I've lived over 3 years in this town without ever having heard of this restaurant! And you wouldn't know it when you enter the place. As you enter, it looks cool, with some walls inexplicably hanging pictures from Tintin ¿? The the waiter comes. He looked like the typical Spanish waiter. But this young fellow wasn't hurried, and he seemed friendlier. We were a party of around 12, representing around 5 different nationalities, and he made the effort to expalin the options to everyone. Then the food came. And only at that moment you realize you are dining in a very special place. Different tapas and other dishes kept coming one after the other, each one as great as the previous one. Everyone in the group was just dazzled! I'd really love to keep this place as a "hidden jewel". However, through the years I've got so many times such valuable guidance from fellow Tripadvisor reviewers, that I feel I'm obliged to share this experience. A few days later I returned with my family, as it ocassionally happens that ones tends to idealize an experience. But this was not the case. They delivered good consistent service, and the best, most creative, tastiest food you could have.  You gotta try it. Don't be put off by the location, it's just a 10 minute ride from downtown, and a 5 minute ride from Barajas airport (if you happen to have a couple of hours to spare in the city). Finally, about the price: This place IS NOT cheap.

review_preview: Madrid, city of culture, sophistication and wonderful, beautiful people.If you want that - then do yourself a favour and go to the Bahia Taberna. I took my partner for his birthday dinner and was we were blown away. Yes, the taxi cost a little...
review_full: Madrid, city of culture, sophistication and wonderful, beautiful people. If you want that - then do yourself a favour and go to the Bahia Taberna. I took my partner for his birthday dinner and was we were blown away. Yes, the taxi cost a little bit more than a small trip to the centre of town, but given the quality, quantity and extraordinary value, why worry about a few euros more?? We had the degustacion menu - a tasting menu - which was simply sublime. Two appetisers and then the most amazing experience, whereby the chef came out and introduced virtually all of the plates. The flavour, ambience and discourse was utterly superb. If there is something that you really don't like (in our case, prawns and mushrooms), then a pre-amble will ensure you don't get what you don't want. Cool, chic, relaxed. If you want great taste, without the pretension, then seek out this first-class restaurant and bar. My thanks to Bea(trice) and all of the staff for making this the best dining experience I've had in many a year. When I emailed the restaurant from Scotland, I got a reply within seconds and a phone call not long after. Customer service which is second to none, food to write home about (and try to emulate at home) and a real sense of being part of an extended family make this the idea stop in Madrid. Think tapas with a European twist, and you won't go far wrong. Banana bread topped with love and loveliness, monkfish which is far from being in the monastery and steak ravioli which reminds us (at least) of the lightest of steak pies. Oh, and desserts which have no equal. Go. Enjoy. And go again. You. Will. Love. It. Muy muchas gracias Bea y Bahia. Mucho gusto y espero comer otra mas!!! James and Christopher

review_preview: When I walk into a restaurant I have not visited before, by the smells and the looks, I am usually able to predict what the experience will be. In this case, I was flat out wrong. The eating area has no more than 6 tables...
review_full: When I walk into a restaurant I have not visited before, by the smells and the looks, I am usually able to predict what the experience will be. In this case, I was flat out wrong. The eating area has no more than 6 tables and it looks pretty uninteresting. However, the experience was wonderful. We went there for lunch and ordered the menu degustación, a total of 5 dishes between appetizers, entrees and desert. The winners were the pizza of chipirones (little calamari) and the ravioli of rabo de toro (bull's tail), but everything was delicious. The service was also very good. Perhaps the only thing that took away from the experience was the atmosphere of the dining area. The room is rather small and the kitchen is right next to it. I think that the atmosphere of the eating area is important to the overall enjoyment. Nevertheless, I highly recommend this restaurant and I will certainly go back.

review_preview: We lucked out on this one. My fiance is staying in Madrid one block away. The service was top-notch, everyone was accommodating and welcoming. The food was standout in all respects. Avant garde technique and presentation frames classical Spanish dishes and ingredients for a fresh...
review_full: We lucked out on this one. My fiance is staying in Madrid one block away. The service was top-notch, everyone was accommodating and welcoming. The food was standout in all respects. Avant garde technique and presentation frames classical Spanish dishes and ingredients for a fresh and exciting take on tapas, i.e. the roasted (as opposed to fried) patatas bravas served with an elegantly light foamed Sriracha aioli. Beer and wine selection is extensive and priced right. We will definitely be frequent visitors at Bahia Taberna.

review_preview: We booked in advance for lunch as advised on TA and we're glad we did. We were about the only ones in when we arrived for lunch at 1.30pm but within minutes the place was full and people were being turned away. The owner couldn't...
review_full: We booked in advance for lunch as advised on TA and we're glad we did. We were about the only ones in when we arrived for lunch at 1.30pm but within minutes the place was full and people were being turned away. The owner couldn't have been more friendly when he showed us our table and the great service continued throughout by all members of staff. We went for the great value Daily Menu and it was so tasty, particularly the risotto starter (huge portion). The house wine that came with it was excellent and we ordered a second glass each. Despite being really busy we were never rushed, even though there was a queue forming outside. We enjoyed it so much that after we left we booked online for dinner later in the week. Again, our welcome was so friendly and I was called by my first name throughout by the owner as if I was a regular. They really appreciate repeat business and make you feel very welcome. My wife had the fillet mignon as her main course and it was a massive piece of meat, cooked to perfection. I had the excellent octopus dish. As per the lunch service earlier in the week you really need to book ahead but it's very easy to do it online. We won't hesitate to come back to this lovely, cosy restaurant next time we're in Madrid.

After a couple of hours from landing and checking into a small hostel I wandered around and feeling the need for an espresso popped into this restaurant. The smell of food made me hungry, so I ended up having a meal. Cost was Euro40 and for main courses the last of which I struggled to eat half, because by then I was well and truly stuffed. There were a couple of tiny snacky things and then the first plate of foie gras on toasted banana bread, wow what an amazing combination. This was followed by baby squid on bread with pesto and other tasty sauces. third plate was sashimi salmon and by the time I finished this I was really ready for my coffee and a snooze, but the final plate of slow cooked lamb, shredded and formed into a small brick with hoisin sauce. I barely ate half of it and was finished, although I did have a double espresso, but no dessert. The staff were very helpful and the chefs even served a couple of the dishes explaining in their "English" what was in each dish. title_review: Oh so good! Thankyou from Australia.
review_preview: We were staying in a hotel nearby as part of a conference and we were getting tired of the mass buffet style food that was being served up and were still searching for that authentic Spanish style food experience after getting the touristy experience in...
review_full: We were staying in a hotel nearby as part of a conference and we were getting tired of the mass buffet style food that was being served up and were still searching for that authentic Spanish style food experience after getting the touristy experience in the city. So after reading the reviews we decided this was the place to go. There were 6 of us in the group and we didn't make a booking, so we got lucky that they had room for us. Once inside we were advised that the restaurant was not going to be open for another 30 minutes. Not a problem, take a seat in the bar area and relax.  The restaurant itself is small but I like the fact that the kitchen is literally right there. You can see all of the goings on in the kitchen and the plating up at the pass. Menu's are set in old vinyl style records. But really you don't need a menu as all the courses are made on the day depending on the produce they get in. The menu is really asking what type of degustation you want. Starters consisted of a Cauliflower and then a ginger Vichyssoise. The cauliflower was ok but the Vichyssoise was excellent. 1st course was scallops. These weren't overcooked and chewy rather soft and melt in the mouth style and sat beautifully on a lovely granite style brick. Great creativity. 2nd course was a baby squid pizza. Some in the group were not keen at the description but were blown away when it came out. Not a scrap was left on any of the plates, 3rd course was monkfish that was sublime. Softly cooked with beautiful flavours. The best dish I experienced all night. A standout. 4th course was Lamb. Once again it just fell apart it was cooked so wonderfully. Desert was cheesecake followed by a chocolate mousse. Once again absolutely beautiful. And to top it off a chocolate truffle. The chef was absolutely fantastic. He also took our orders and described everything that was made. Outgoing personality, not pretentious in anyway at all. We all left absolutely delighted at finding such a beautiful Spanish restaurant not in a touristy area. If you are visiting Madrid and want to experience beautiful food for a very good price with friendly service then look no further than here. Highly recommended!

review_preview: We looked forward to visiting this restaurant, and we were warmly greeted apon arrival. And from there on, it went down hill.. 1) The cava was totally dead. 2) They made me glutenfree potatos on request, but than served me potatos with gluten under the...
review_full: We looked forward to visiting this restaurant, and we were warmly greeted apon arrival. And from there on, it went down hill.. 1) The cava was totally dead. 2) They made me glutenfree potatos on request, but than served me potatos with gluten under the beef. As a result, I got sick during the night after my visit to the restaurant! 3) The beef was totally raw, and we had to send it back. 4) The waitress managed to spill the bottle of wine over my friend and her jacket (and the woman at the next table). 5) There was a dead COCKROACH under our table. This was spotted and removed by the owner, as he was cleaning up the wine on the floor after spilling it. AND in the end, we were rudely asked to leave, becuse they needed the table for other guests! I have never in my life had an worse restaurant experiance, and I do want to point out, that we were never rude or complained loudly. Still they treated us poorly and we had to pay 90 Euro for two glasses of cava, two starters, two main courses and one bottle of wine. Quite expencive and no discount.. We will never return!

review_preview: Ate here with my partner after a long flight from the Middle East to Madrid - I am so glad we did! Loved every plate they put in front of us, and our waiter Miguel was extremely helpful (particularly by explaining all the dishes in...
review_full: Ate here with my partner after a long flight from the Middle East to Madrid - I am so glad we did! Loved every plate they put in front of us, and our waiter Miguel was extremely helpful (particularly by explaining all the dishes in English since neither of us speak Spanish!) and all of the staff were incredibly knowledgeable about the dishes. Also had an excellent wine list. We had 6 courses, and it was perfectly apportioned and timed so no feeling "stuffed" at the end, just a delightful combination of tastes and textures. These guys know - and love- their food.  If you have a reasonably adventurous palette and enjoy lovingly-prepared food and wine eaten in unpretentious surrounding, you won't go far wrong with Bahia Taberna. We will be back!!

It is located near the airport in a quiet area and is not somewhere that you would stumble across by accident. You, however, MUST get in a taxi and visit as soon as you can as the food is outstanding and interesting.  The waiter advised us to allow the chef to chose a selection of dishes and this is definitely the way to go. Everything was delicious and there was nothing we did not enjoy. It is creative, very well presented, the service is attentive and friendly and to top it off the best gin and tonic you will get anywhere in the world - seriously! I predict this restaurant will grow and grow, this must be top of your list for a great meal out.

review_preview: We were searching for a great paella restaurant reasonably priced. The Marina Ventura proved to be much more. We went on a Sunday for lunch and were lucky to make reservations as when we arrived they were not able to take care of what seemed...
review_full: We were searching for a great paella restaurant reasonably priced. The Marina Ventura proved to be much more. We went on a Sunday for lunch and were lucky to make reservations as when we arrived they were not able to take care of what seemed to be regular clients without reservations. We arrived at 1,30 pm and after 2,20 pm the place was packed although the setup of tables at the restaurant does not make you feel in a crowded place. Very nice looking, modern restaurant with very professional service located at Barrio de las Letras, a short walk from the Sevilla Metro Station. We had baked cheese with caramelised onions for start. It is composed of baked goat and brie cheeses which are just delicious.Two very generous portions of each cheese for 13.5 Euros.  We then had the Arroz mixto Señoret. A great paella rice for those who do not like peeling hot seafood with your hands at the table. The rice was cooked to perfection with generous amounts of seafood, chicken and pork, all for a very reasonable 17 Euros per person. We also had a bottle of albarino for 18 Euros. In short we had a memorable lunch at a great location with very professional service for a very reasonable price. This restaurant is now in our top list of favorites while in Madrid.

review_preview: My husband and I stopped here for dinner on Jan. 11.  We found it with an online search for restaurants near the airport, but we were not expecting anything very special.  Luckily for us, we stumbled onto an absolutely wonderful restaurant.  We took the degustacion...
review_full: My husband and I stopped here for dinner on Jan. 11. We found it with an online search for restaurants near the airport, but we were not expecting anything very special. Luckily for us, we stumbled onto an absolutely wonderful restaurant. We took the degustacion menu and were totally amazed at the creativity, subtlety of the food and its preparation. Each course was outstanding and so attentively served that we were totally astounded and, of course, delighted. If you have to spend the night near Barajas Airport, as we did, this is a wonderful opportunity for fine dining.   The restaurant itself is small and not especially fancy, though they have a small area set up with the full linens and plates of a fancy restaurant. You can see the chefs at work. The price for this outstanding meal was very inexpensive considering the product delivered.   Thanks to Bahia Taverna for an unexpected terrific meal before leaving Spain.

review_preview: My wife and 2-year-old daughter ate here twice during our 4-night stay in Madrid. We took food away on our first night as our daughter was already tired. We returned for lunch at the restaurant on our penultimate day. Our hotel recommended this restaurant for...
review_full: My wife and 2-year-old daughter ate here twice during our 4-night stay in Madrid. We took food away on our first night as our daughter was already tired. We returned for lunch at the restaurant on our penultimate day. Our hotel recommended this restaurant for paella. Despite being recommended by our hotel, it was thankfully not a tourist trap.  We ordered paella Valenciana and grilled vegetables for takeaway. It was alright but we found that it had too many Lima beans overpowering the flavor of the rice and chicken. When we returned for lunch with a larger group, we ordered arroz negro (with squid) and arroz campero (with chicken, rabbit, etc) along with lamb (chuletitas de cordero) and chopitos (fried squid). We shared a pitcher of sangria. The paellas were excellent, especially the arroz negro. The chopitos were delicious as well, and the lamb chops were quite tasty. Service was good, with the waiter speaking good English. It should be noted however that one waitress became particularly snarky simply because I called her señora rather than señorita when I was trying to speak a bit of Spanish. This waitress avoided eye contact with me throughout the rest of our stay at the restaurant. The ambience of the restaurant is classy and cozy, and yet quite spacious. We didn’t have any problems parking our stroller next to our table. This restaurant is rather pricey, with a minimum paella order for two persons. You will therefore spend at least EUR 32 if you want to order paella. In spite of this waitress’s behavior, I would recommend this restaurant.

Food looked and tasted great, good wine list, staff were very friendly and helpful even with our terrible Spanish. Definitely worth a relaxed lunch or dinner. Hats of to the creative Chef!

title_review: Worst paella I have had in Spain!
review_preview: We went to Marina Ventura thinking that it is a place above average and we would have a delicious sea food paella. First of all, most of the photos are misleading. We have been served a sea-food paella for 4 people. There were only 5...
review_full: We went to Marina Ventura thinking that it is a place above average and we would have a delicious sea food paella. First of all, most of the photos are misleading. We have been served a sea-food paella for 4 people. There were only 5 slices of calamari, a few tiny prawns (not king prawns as in the photos) that were almost impossible to find inside the paella and 8 pieces of unshelled mussels. Yes, you heard me right! It had nothing to do with the photos full of shelled mussels, king prawns and calamari. We could barely see sea food inside our paella. Plus, rice was undercooked that we could not eat it. It was definitely the worst paella I have had in Spain and I am counting the fast-food style paella places into this!!! We had a calamari, a paella for 4 people, 1 bottle of water and 4 soft drinks for our dinner and paid 35 euros each (140 total). I strongly recommend you to try somewhere else if you want to have sea food paella with real and visible sea food in it. I guess the number of sea food will be more than the number of fingers in one hand when you pay an amount similar to ours!!!

title_review: Great paella.  Highly recommend this restaurant.
review_preview: We shared the 'A Banda” seafood paella which was really really good.  The paellas are for a minimum of two people and you're told that as its cooked fresh it will take around 30-40 minutes to arrive.  We ordered some bread to start with, along...
review_full: We shared the 'A Banda” seafood paella which was really really good. The paellas are for a minimum of two people and you're told that as its cooked fresh it will take around 30-40 minutes to arrive. We ordered some bread to start with, along with a bottle of cava, while waiting for the paella. We were served a large warm bread roll each along with some soft cheese with a little pesto which was very tasty.  The paella seemed to be ready quicker than expected and was really tasty. It was huge and much more than we could both eat. We both enjoyed trying the large scarlet shrimp for the first time, and also enjoyed the king prawns, shrimp, clams and mussels within the paella. Service was good, although the waiters and waitresses did come over to the table a lot more than it felt they needed to.  Overall a great meal that we highy recommend.

title_review: Creative sit down tapas in a cozy setting.
review_preview: Casa Lucas is on the usual "tapas craw" circuit, on Calle Cava Baja in Madrid. However, the food is spectacular.  It is a step above usual tapas, with a creative flair.  Strongly recommend making reservations so you can have a sit down meal.  While the...
review_full: Casa Lucas is on the usual "tapas craw" circuit, on Calle Cava Baja in Madrid. However, the food is spectacular. It is a step above usual tapas, with a creative flair. Strongly recommend making reservations so you can have a sit down meal. While the tapas are great ,don't overlook the "raciones" - the entrees. We had an oxtail (rabo de toro) stew made with prunes and pistachios on a bed of creamy mashed potatoes. They have a wonderful wine selection as well - reasonably priced.

review_preview: Almost since they opened 5 years ago, I have been a monthly visitor to the "Bahia Taberna", by far the best place near the airport in Madrid and worth wile the 15 mins taxi drive from downtown Madrid.In these 5 years, I have seen...
review_full: Almost since they opened 5 years ago, I have been a monthly visitor to the "Bahia Taberna", by far the best place near the airport in Madrid and worth wile the 15 mins taxi drive from downtown Madrid. In these 5 years, I have seen Chef Dani and his team excel, day by day. I have never repeated dishes across seasons, except for the classics that the locals request to stay in the menu. With very deep Italian background and high dominance of the technique, Dani has created a universe of single plate gourmet tapas with a very recognizable identity. Sashimis, tartars, slow cooked meats and an abundance of warm and cold seasons veggies including a landmark gazpacho are the must haves. Depending on how hungry you are, Dani will propose you a 3 to 7 tapas tasting menu that will always be in better price/quality than any other place in Madrid. Make sure you book your table in advance as local business man at lunch time and foreign tourists at dinner normally block the 8 tables in the main room. Also, consider a walk in and enjoy the same menu at their high tables with a signature gin tonic. By far, my favorite place in Madrid, Spain and Europe. They even rewarded my loyalty with a cocktail named by me "Expresso Karani" (their own interpretation of the Expresso Martini).

review_preview: I had bookmarked this place before I left and on our first night we woke up late from a much needed nap and starving.  Luckily eating late had us fitting right in in Madrid!  We found our way to La Berenjena and grabbed a few...
review_full: I had bookmarked this place before I left and on our first night we woke up late from a much needed nap and starving. Luckily eating late had us fitting right in in Madrid! We found our way to La Berenjena and grabbed a few empty stools by the door. We ordered from the very nice female bartender, the man I assume spoke very little English because whenever we approached he signaled for her, which was funny because we did tend to order in Spanish. Anyway, she was great and after we ended up moving away from the front to a an area in the back and she came by to recommend some food and wine for me, the boys were drinking the local beer all night. Everything we ordered was great. I wish I had more of an appetite because I would have loved to try more things. But I can say the burrata salad was perfect, the tomatoes were ripe and the truffle oil just right, add some crusty bread and I was very happy. We also split an assortment of croquettes, the mushroom and the leek. The leek were my favorite and I say that as someone obsessed with mushrooms. I forget what the guys ordered but they were happy. Prices were very reasonable, as all of Madrid seemed to be. And we had a really fun first night in the city!

review_preview: What to say when you enter in a real “taberna”, with tables in rough wood, and taste a high-kitchen series of dishes? This restaurant surprised all of us with its evident contrast between appearance and quality: it seems to be a mid—low level place where...
review_full: What to say when you enter in a real “taberna”, with tables in rough wood, and taste a high-kitchen series of dishes? This restaurant surprised all of us with its evident contrast between appearance and quality: it seems to be a mid—low level place where you actually experience something well above even pretty good restaurants.  We took 4 dishes+desserts, where you can taste a broad variety of different foods and preparations, often re-elaborating local dishes (e.g. the baby squid), presented every time in a different way, well served and represented by the waiter. Every bite is an explosion of flavors, not far from my experience in Michelin-starred restaurants. Also some unexpected food is provided as part of the sequence.  We spent less than 50 euros each including beverages (we stay a bit limited on them, so you can expect to spend a bit more) but again the food experience is excellent.

review_preview: Went there basis TA and was not disappointed. We went just after 9pm as suggested because it became very crowded by 10ish and we did not have a reservation. They got us a table for two very quickly and the waiter knew English and had...
review_full: Went there basis TA and was not disappointed. We went just after 9pm as suggested because it became very crowded by 10ish and we did not have a reservation. They got us a table for two very quickly and the waiter knew English and had an English menu. The menu is limited but very innovative. Not the average tapas you get at most places like Spanish omelette or chorizo. The highlight was the tomato and goat cheese salad with lovely olive oil and fresh basil. We also had chicken and pork on bread which was lovely. 6 tapas and a couple of glasses of cava came under £50 which was a great bargain. If you are at Cava Baja and looking for a place to eat then do go here. It's nothing fantastic as some of the reviews suggest but it will definitely won't disappoint you.

review_preview: Went for dinner with my partner and was swept off my feet by the whole place. It is a local unpretentious bar, but the kitchen is pumping out top quality food (as in the best meal I’ve had in Madrid, type quality!).The place was...
review_full: Went for dinner with my partner and was swept off my feet by the whole place. It is a local unpretentious bar, but the kitchen is pumping out top quality food (as in the best meal I’ve had in Madrid, type quality!). The place was packed full with locals, many of whom knew the waiter/bartender very well and shared a shot with him before leaving. They have a Spanish and English menu. The waiter/bartender didn’t speak a word of English (and I speak very very limited Spanish) but he was very friendly, patient and enthusiastic to communicate (including simply by pointing). We had: 4 beers 8 wines 1 water 1 serving of fried soft shell crabs 1 serving of skirt steak 1 serving of prawn gyoza 1 serving of grilled eggplant  1 chocolate brownie  1 mousse/ chocolate dessert  For 83€ We also shared a (free) shot with the bartender before we left! I cannot recommend this place enough!

It's unacceptable specially for a restaurant which pretends to be exclusive and refined. They demonstrate superficiality and carelessness and that’s for me it’s just unjustifiable. Absolutely unreliable. A place simply to not consider for any plan.

review_preview: First went here 10 years ago when it was half the size.  Since then they have expanded physically and culinarily.  Took the long tasting menu.  Good quantities and not too long at €52 / head good value. With 1 exception only 1 dish was repeated...
review_full: First went here 10 years ago when it was half the size. Since then they have expanded physically and culinarily.  Took the long tasting menu. Good quantities and not too long at €52 / head good value.  With 1 exception only 1 dish was repeated from last visit a couple of months ago. All good fresh and tasty. A few dishes a little spicy - just a tang not over powering. Only one I wasn’t keen on was pigs totters - too jelly like for me. But the rest excellent. Anchovies good, lovely beef and very nice tuna. Desserts good too. Definitely one to visit on the outskirts of Madrid so need to make it a trip parks nearby (Juan Carlos or Capricho).

title_review: One of the best restaurants in Madrid - chef Dani rocks!
review_preview: Simply fabulous - I try to come back here (or Derzu, same owner) anytime I'm in Madrid. Two areas: a dining room for a gourmet sampling menu (which I haven't tried yet), and a more high-table area at the entrance, closer to the bar, for...
review_full: Simply fabulous - I try to come back here (or Derzu, same owner) anytime I'm in Madrid. Two areas: a dining room for a gourmet sampling menu (which I haven't tried yet), and a more high-table area at the entrance, closer to the bar, for a more informal experience. They are constantly renewing their menu, so they are able to surprise you anytime you come back. Impressive wine list, full of not-so-well-known but high-quality names. Very professional service, with the best maitre d' (Alvaro) you can imagine. Definitely, value for your money.

title_review: I forgot I was in Spain
review_preview: It’s hard to say this, in a country with incredible cuisine, but my evening at this restaurant, made me think that I was back in Italy. The food was very authentic! From the first moment you walk into this restaurant, the aromas are real Italian....
review_full: It’s hard to say this, in a country with incredible cuisine, but my evening at this restaurant, made me think that I was back in Italy. The food was very authentic! From the first moment you walk into this restaurant, the aromas are real Italian. I would strongly recommend the mozzarella Forno, the muscles were a great surprise particularly in the marinara sauce they were prepared in, and the pasta is as fresh as fresh gets. The carbonara is very rich, but well deserving. The pizza was delicious with the buffala mozzarella margarita pizza a standout. Leave room for dessert, with the tiramisu being particularly good. The wine selection is great. Some of the staff, have a little trouble understanding English, so please be patient. They are truly wonderful hard-working people. On the last note, try getting a table upstairs. The downstairs felt very claustrophobic.

The servers are top notch and fun. Luckily we were able to eat there the following night as well. I cannot recommend this restaurant enough. It's easy to find...across from the famous Churro with chocolate cafe and a few steps from the Plaza Mayor. Put this on your list when you visit. You won't regret it.

title_review: If you're going to the fair...
review_preview: My wife and I were at the Madrid contemporary art fair and right next to "Feria de Madrid". We were at a big business hotel and eating at such a place seemed a bit sad. We pulled up Tripadvisor and saw that the "best restaurant"...
review_full: My wife and I were at the Madrid contemporary art fair and right next to "Feria de Madrid". We were at a big business hotel and eating at such a place seemed a bit sad. We pulled up Tripadvisor and saw that the "best restaurant" on the site was just a 4 km cab ride away and so we went for it.  The pictures on Trip Advisor showed a small rather sterile-looking restaurant, but the vibe and contemporary decoration was better than I had expected.  The menu seemed a bit small: perhaps 10 or 15 total choices. And all of the choices were rather exotic, and so it wasn't like we could simply order a paella and know what we were getting. As most people on TA, we went with the "discovery menu". Basically, they take 7 or 8 of the menu items and split into two portions.  Everything came quickly and was well presented. We bought a bottle of 20 Euro wine which was excellent. Yep...the chef came out and spoke with us, explaining everything to us in Spanish/French/English.  Really...a good experience and yes...my best meal in Madrid thus far. My only (small) complaint is that my wife and I both agreed that the portions good have been larger. I remember that there were a few courses that consisted of one (single) "amuse-bouche" size portion. I realize that this place isn't a trough, but there really was hardly enough to taste. That said, I didn't leave hungry and I've got a good appetite.  The total bill: a few beers, a bottle of wine and two menus came to 100 Euros.  If you're in the area, it's worth the cab fare.

title_review: Book now! Our new favourite restaurant in Madrid
review_preview: Having read the reviews on line, we decided to book on line and asked a few questions regarding options for my veggie wife. i received an email response within minutes then a phone call. excellent start! we booked the tasting menu for 5 people (1...
review_full: Having read the reviews on line, we decided to book on line and asked a few questions regarding options for my veggie wife. i received an email response within minutes then a phone call. excellent start! we booked the tasting menu for 5 people (1 child 1 veggie), sunday lunch time 13h. the restaurant is a 10 minute drive from home and very easy to find, although in an unusual location in a regular neighbourhood. parking was no problem. there were already people there, and we were greeted by a smiling guy, by name. again a nice touch. great table right by the open plan kitchen. smiling head chef, who couldnt wait to start producing the dishes. again they confirmed we had a veggie in the group. so the food...fresh, creative, unusual, cooked to perfection, presented beautifully, served at a steady pace but not at all rushed. each dish was explained in english and spanish. (all the staff we met spoke good english, to compliment my bad spanish). dishes included...Roasted pumpkin, foie gras with banana cake and pineapple crisps, rabo de torro (the best dish in my opinion) cod with chick pea cocido, baby squid, scallops with bacon and celeraic mash (im sure i have missed something). the dessert menu was also spectacular...tastiest tiramisu ever, divine cheesecake, the chocolate brownie kept the child quiet! my wife said the veggie dishes were the best she has tasted anywhere. (we are well travelled). being a veggie is spain can be hard work, especially in madrid, but here the dishes took as high priority as the regular dishes. i tasted each veggie dish and can confirm they were excellent. its normal to be able to find small things wrong with some restaurants...but honestly everything was perfect. at the end the chef presented us with the menu...a lovely idea for a souvenir. everyone in the restaurant seems to enjoy working there...happy smiling and calm staff really enhances the atmosphere. the cost..worked out at 55 € per head, this included. tasting menu for 5. 3 glasses of wine, plus a bottle of wine, 3 glasses of 20 year old pedro jimenez dessert wine, 3 coca colas, 3 bottles of water, 1 beer. i think thats very reasonable given the quality of the food and overall experience. we will be going back within the next 2 weeks. i strongly recommend this restaurant. we have eaten in michelin star restaurants, and this is equivalent standard. its only a matter of time before demand will merit a city centre location, but for now, head out and enjoy while you can. 10/10.

title_review: One of the best meals I have ever had in my life.
review_preview: This is definitely one of the best meals I have ever had in my life. I am always too lazy to write reviews, but this restaurant deserves the time I dedicate to remember such a great meal. The service excellent, with the chef coming to...
review_full: This is definitely one of the best meals I have ever had in my life. I am always too lazy to write reviews, but this restaurant deserves the time I dedicate to remember such a great meal. The service excellent, with the chef coming to our table to go over the plates; the atmosphere, relaxed but interesting, hip but in a classy way. Definitely go there if you want to have a fantastic gourmet experience. Stayed in Madrid for our last night, and found the restaurant recommended by TripAdvisor. We wanted to go to a better restaurant with my brother, and we didn't mind splurging one night. The prices were not shown in the website, but they pointed to ~40 EUR/person, and they were right (including a single glass of wine and dessert). The meal was memorable. The waiter went over the really small menu, and served us a degustation menu, with 4 delicious meals: * One patata brava, literally one, while we waited * Pizza de chipiron -unbelievable. A masterpiece * Zucchini with blue cheese.  and the ones i still think about: * A salmon tartar * Steak tartar The ingredients were all perfect, fresh, combining perfectly. I still think of these plates one month after we had them.  For dessert we had an unbelievable Tiramisu. So tasteful.  We went to a well recommended restaurant (but lower price point) in Seattle just last night. Still thinking about that meal, it made it look like fast food. The restaurant is in an odd neighborhood, very close to the airport but far away from the center. It's worth the trip :-)

title_review: Good food and service - but gets crowded
review_preview: Situated on Cava Baja in Madrid's La Latina neighbourhood, Casa Lucas catered for both locals and tourists, with menus available in English. It's a very small bar, with about four tables and some stools at the bar where you can also order tapas. We visited...
review_full: Situated on Cava Baja in Madrid's La Latina neighbourhood, Casa Lucas catered for both locals and tourists, with menus available in English.  It's a very small bar, with about four tables and some stools at the bar where you can also order tapas. We visited around 8pm on a Saturday evening and enjoyed a drink at the bar whilst waiting for a table. By the time we were leaving after 9pm, the place was full of people waiting so I'd recommend going early (by Madrid standards!).  As everyone else has said, the wines are excellent and the service good. The waiter spoke English and explained the different types of Spanish wine available as we wanted an alternative to the usual rioja wines. The tapas menu wasn't extensive, but the small selection didn't disappoint.  Definately recommended if you're looking for modern, innovative tapas in Madrid.

review_preview: I had an over night lay over at Madrid and as I arrived in the evening, I opted to stay near the airport . I am delighted to say Bahia Taberan is a fabulous restaurant at which to dine if any where near this area...
review_full: I had an over night lay over at Madrid and as I arrived in the evening, I opted to stay near the airport . I am delighted to say Bahia Taberan is a fabulous restaurant at which to dine if any where near this area or want to take a jaunt from more central Madrid! It is bright and small and you can reserve ahead of time, which I did pursuant to learning of its excellent reputation. It is a casual and hip atmosphere. There is an option between tall tables and ...covered tables? (not sure precise term)(not sure if they actually were covered). The tall tables are more communal (long so that many can sit at it) and that area gets busy/full as the evening proceeds. If you are having the tasting menu , it is best to perhaps reserve the other tables which are further back from entry door and are in a more restaurant typical arrangement (less communal as separate tables). While the server spoke English, there were still some challenges but I had the short menu and could have changed it to the long and think maybe I should have as frankly, everything was absolutely delicious (I wistfully eyed the dishes of those who did have the long taste menu). But I was full (unfortunately), so just had the short tasting menu (sigh) (still not sure of this decision..ha). I highly recommend this restaurant. Every thing that comes out is a true taste treat and they take care with what you drink also. I truly recommend.

We had the tasting menu...lots of little dishes with inventive combinations, beautifully prepared and simply superb. The enthusiasm of the chef shines through. This was far and away the best meal we had in Spain, and probably the best value anywhere. Worth coming out from Central Madrid for.
