title_review: The Best in Madrid 5 mins drive from the airport
review_preview: Dani Vangoni at the Bahia Taberna is redefining advanced gourmet dining at very affordable prices. Dani has reinterpreted the "taberna" concept without losing the humble foundation of home-made meals that he serves in single tapas plates. 4 or 5 of those single tapas will just...
review_full: Dani Vangoni at the Bahia Taberna is redefining advanced gourmet dining at very affordable prices. Dani has reinterpreted the "taberna" concept without losing the humble foundation of home-made meals that he serves in single tapas plates. 4 or 5 of those single tapas will just make your meal. These will normally include his very own interpretations of foie, calamari, sashimi tuna and iberian "pata negra" pork. His Italian influence also gets noticed in his rissottos and pastas that he will cook you on demand when becoming a regular. The casual cool setting in Bahia invites for a gin tonic or premium rhum (not to forget the frapped ice grappa) after any of his landmarks desserts (peaches tatin is my favourite choice). Enjoy Madrid at his best with Dani at the Bahia!

review_preview: After seeing the high ranking of the TripAdvisor, we though of booking a table in between flights. We though it would be a sophisticated tavern judging from the name and looking at the dishes' photos. Ofcourse looking at the location which is off the beaten...
review_full: After seeing the high ranking of the TripAdvisor, we though of booking a table in between flights. We though it would be a sophisticated tavern judging from the name and looking at the dishes' photos. Ofcourse looking at the location which is off the beaten track away from everything that would be slightly touristic, we though, hmmm...... is this really the place? Given the fact though that its location is a 7-8 minutes taxi ride from the airport we though that it was a no brainer. We took the Metro to the closest stop (Alameda de Osuna) from the line 5 we were on. Then we needed a 15 minute walk to reach the Bahia taberna. Arriving at 20:30 (8:30 pm) we were the first customers (Spanish usually go out to eat after 21:00. We explained that we needed to leave around 22:00 to catch our plane. We expected to be seated in one of the bar-like high tables made of euro-pallets (nice idea and nice ambiance), we finally were seated in one of the few low tables close to the kitchen. Here is were we realized that there was a small variation of the menu and the pricing when seated at the bar-like tables comparing to seating at a normal table. At that point I thought that we would be paying a lot more than expected. Our initial expectation from a taverna was around €20 per person. We thought though giving it a try. We explained that we would prefer having fish and we asked them to feel free and build up the menu for us. We found all the dishes FANTASTIC! What a great combination of great ingredients presented in a Michelin star way. One dish was tastier than the other. The speed of serving was also remarkable having the chef and the waiter worrying more than we did about getting a taxi to the airport and avoiding missing our flight. What a service! We finally ended up paying less than €90 for two persons with a glass of wine and two bottles of water. I truly hope that the prices will be kept in a logical levels and as I said to the chef, please do not get a michelin star even though you worth it. So in a nutshell the service is excellent, the food is sublime and it worth while going away from the center to taste the creations of its chef. What an experience!

review_preview: We chanced upon Casa Lucas based on a suggestion from a Spanish policeman guarding traffic at the entrance of the Cava Baja street. What a great suggestion. It was a Saturday and the place was packed with people. We reached at 10:00 pm and were...
review_full: We chanced upon Casa Lucas based on a suggestion from a Spanish policeman guarding traffic at the entrance of the Cava Baja street. What a great suggestion. It was a Saturday and the place was packed with people. We reached at 10:00 pm and were told there would be a 45 mins wait time. So we huddled around the bar and ordered some wine and tapas. We did not know what to expect, but were put to ease as soon as our tapas arrived. The blood sausage and egg on top of bread was divine! (This particular tapas remained the highlight among all the food that we tasted in our 7 day trip in Spain.) We finally got our table and shared a plate of the oxtail balls which was also very good. We came back the next day and had the Huevos Macarena - egg, cream, veggie, mushroom, and ham casserole. This was very good as well. We highly recommend this place. Remember to make reservations before going to this little gem in Madrid.

title_review: Casa Lucas was elected one of the 50 best tapas bar in Madrid, Spain.
review_preview: This is a small tapas bar and one of the best restaurants I had the opportunity to eat in Madrid. It is a new Spanish creative original cuisine where the plates have a great presentation and refined flavor. The owner is always present at the...
review_full: This is a small tapas bar and one of the best restaurants I had the opportunity to eat in Madrid. It is a new Spanish creative original cuisine where the plates have a great presentation and refined flavor. The owner is always present at the bar and service is very personable and friendly. The list of wines are exquisite with a wide selection of Rioja, Crianzas, Blancos and sweet wines. I suggest trying one of the following dishes: *Arroz cremoso con boletus y foie *Pincho de revuelto de morcilla con piñones y pasas sobre tomate confitado. *Solomillo de cerdo con cebolla confitada  *Canelón casero relleno de verduras (to die for!). As I said, you won’t regret going to this tapas bar when in Madrid.

review_preview: My husband and I enjoyed our first dinner during our trip to Madrid at Casa Lucas.  It's a tiny, hopping restaurant that was filled with happy people eating and drinking.  It's not really a tapas place, they have some as sort of appetizers, but also...
review_full: My husband and I enjoyed our first dinner during our trip to Madrid at Casa Lucas. It's a tiny, hopping restaurant that was filled with happy people eating and drinking. It's not really a tapas place, they have some as sort of appetizers, but also quite a few entrees. We had a wonderful salad with tomatoes, goat cheese and lettuce, but the start of the night was the lightly fried, HUGE, tender calamari dish. It had this balsamic and slightly creamy sauce and bacon, and it was by the far the best squid I've ever had. It's also HUGE, we couldn't finish it. We also had 1 glass each of red wine (2 different ones), and they were both great. Highly recommended for an authentic Madrid night with great food.

review_preview: Casa Lucas was recommended on another site so my friends and I gave it a try when in Madrid. When we first stepped in I had my doubts. It's very small and the waiter seemed a bit inconvenienced to have to sit a group of...
review_full: Casa Lucas was recommended on another site so my friends and I gave it a try when in Madrid. When we first stepped in I had my doubts. It's very small and the waiter seemed a bit inconvenienced to have to sit a group of 3 at a table that seats 5. I get that they are busy and that that means not getting maximum value out of your space, but there was nothing else and we came there to spend, so it was a bit off putting when he sighed and reluctantly sat us. However, after that initial less than warm welcome, we totally enjoyed our visit. The food was AMAZING. It's so creative and unusual. We tried a series of Tostas, One had a corn mouse and I thought I'd died and gone to heaven when I put that in my mouth. They had a really interesting drink menu so we tried the vermouth which is a must, and an interesting sherry wine which was totally new to me. I loved the adventurous offerings and all the tastes were rewarding and interesting. I highly recommend a visit to Casa Lucas!

The waiter spoke english well enough for us to be able to order (I found that Madrid is much less tolerant of my bad, schoolboy Spanish than other areas of Spain). I had oxtail with mash puree and my wife had some form of codfish dish. Mine was really nice, Monica's less so. I guess you take your chances when you try something new so we weren't unhappy with the place. It is a bit of a tourist spot though, the table next to us had a couple of French girls and the one after that Americans.

title_review: Different and tasty tapas in a popular tourist eatery
review_preview: This restaurant is extremely popular and by 20:30 (very early for dinner by Spanish standards) there were many people queuing at the bar for one of the 6 tables. The menu selection was slightly different from the usual tapas restaurants we had visited around Madrid...
review_full: This restaurant is extremely popular and by 20:30 (very early for dinner by Spanish standards) there were many people queuing at the bar for one of the 6 tables. The menu selection was slightly different from the usual tapas restaurants we had visited around Madrid but the food was very tasty and the service was quick and friendly. When we were there the clientèle almost exclusively consisted of US visitors, and whilst I have no problem with our fellow English speaking friends, it did just feel that we were in a tourist hotspot rather than an authentic Madrilenos favorite. A victim of it's own success of TA, perhaps? The road on which Casa Lucas is situated (Calle Cava Baja) appeared to have many popular restaurants filled with locals and next time I'm in that part of town I will be more inclined to visit one of these alternatives instead; for the experience rather than for want of better food.

title_review: Small, informal, good Italian in center city Madrid
review_preview: We ate lunch in this little gem today, which in Madrid is much later than in America (3pm).  The menu (only in Spanish) was only a few items but I think that’s better than the street-side restaurants with long, undistinguished food service.  We had croquettes...
review_full: We ate lunch in this little gem today, which in Madrid is much later than in America (3pm). The menu (only in Spanish) was only a few items but I think that’s better than the street-side restaurants with long, undistinguished food service. We had croquettes and mozzarella/sautéed bell peppers/lettuce appetizers that were both well prepared. The zucchini bechamel lasagna entree was very good as was the pasta special of fresh tomatoes/fresh ricotta cheese. review_preview: We visited Trattoria Malatesta the last weekend in September with my family. We had read good reviews about the place and we decided to go for dinner on a Sunday night. We called ahead of time to make a reservation (it is required since it...
review_full: We visited Trattoria Malatesta the last weekend in September with my family. We had read good reviews about the place and we decided to go for dinner on a Sunday night. We called ahead of time to make a reservation (it is required since it is a popular place). We all loved it. The atmosphere was nice (the basement is pretty, but if the weather is nice ask for a table in the ground floor. The don't make reservation for the 3-4 tables they have outside in the front, so go early for those. They are the best). The staff was very polite and friendly (everybody spoke English). We loved the food so much that we had dinner there 3 nights in a row (it was a four nights trip). We end up trying 4 or 5 pasta dishes which were all delicious (My wife loved the mussels and shrimp pasta dish). The house wine was also very good. The tiramisu and panna cotta were to die for. Our bill was between 60 and 80 euros, and that included wine and desert. Value for money. Overall, nice atmosphere, friendly staff, great food. We will definitely go back on our next visit.

Everything was delicious and the service was fantastic. We highly recommend this place.

title_review: Wonderful food, watch out for added costs
review_preview: We (9 of us) went here for dinner and lunch. The menus for both are the same. Drinks were some of the cheapest we found in restaurants in the city (€2 for fizzy drinks and €1.80 for 50cl water) and there was a very large...
review_full: We (9 of us) went here for dinner and lunch. The menus for both are the same. Drinks were some of the cheapest we found in restaurants in the city (€2 for fizzy drinks and €1.80 for 50cl water) and there was a very large selection of pizza and pasta. They also kindly did me pasta with a plain tomato sauce, as i wanted something lighter and it was no problem for them at all. The waiters spoke excellent english (a rarety actually) and were friendly and extremely helpful. The portion sizes were wonderful for dinner, and excellent shared for lunch. There is plenty of seating inside and the outside seating is on a quiet but atmospheric side street. The first timne we went we sat outside, which was wonderful, however a 10% 'supplemento terraza' was added to the bill (which is large for a group of 9, basically adding the cost of another full meal on the bill). Also VAT (IVA at 8%) is not added on the menu, but added on the bill. This was no problem, but it did make dividing up what was owed difficult. Apart from these minor setbacks we did return (and ate inside, which was lovely and quiet and cool) and thoroughly enjoyed it once again.  It's funny to find such authentic and delicious italian food in a spanish city, but it really hit the spot with our group, and if we returned to madrid we would most definitely go back!

review_preview: Casa Lucas is a must visit on your trip to Madrid.  In a street that is end to end tapas you should definitely go here. There are small tapas such as the Madrid which is a gorgeous mix of morcilla with sweet onion relish on...
review_full: Casa Lucas is a must visit on your trip to Madrid. In a street that is end to end tapas you should definitely go here. There are small tapas such as the Madrid which is a gorgeous mix of morcilla with sweet onion relish on bread - one of their classics and very popular and only €6.  There is a relatively short Menu of tapas ranging from €15 to €25 but the portions are big and you would need to share the dishes unless you had a very, very healthy appetite - we are big eaters but we would still share! This time we ordered the squid wrapped in bacon with squid ink and it was fantastic. It comes well presented in parcels of battered squid wrapped in bacon but once the waiter has chopped and mixed it with the squid ink it looks lik a totally different dish and tastes fabulous.  On a previous visit in October we had eaten the classic Rabo del Toro and the pulpo (octopus on a mound of saffron potatoes ) and I had been looking forward to having the squid since then an I wasn't disappointed. review_full: Casa Lucas is sandwiched between many good restaurants just south of Plaza Mayor. It has to be good because the other restaurants have more space, more waiters and better decore. Creamy potato on chicken with carmelized onion on toasted bread.  Because we didn't have reservations, we arrived at 8:05PM. Good thing because by 9:00 there were a lot of people waiting. The management eased their wait time by offering wine or beer to drink, standing up.  The space is small and tables simple. Service was efficient. Our waiter (one of 2?) took our order perfectly but was quite busy. He never showed the strain but in a 1 room restaurant, we could all see that he was the only one flyng around serving everyone. 2 waters, 3 wines,5 tapas came to 71.50 Euro.

review_full: Myself and my boyfriend (both 21) arrived at this restaurant after reading the reviews on tripadvisor. Understanding from the reviews that it is busy and a booking may be required, we headed towards this restaurant hoping we would be seated. As we arrived it was obvious it was busy. A man skipped us and asked for a table for 2 and the waiter said it will be a couple of minutes but you can wait across the way. I asked them for a table for two and he said “ah no that will be impossible, not until 11 o clock”. Unfortunate but we understood. We stepped to the side to find another restaurant online to eat in, to see another couple come up and ask for a table for two and again they were told it wouldn’t be too long and to step to the side with the other couple. I am not sure if this is because we look young or if they just pick customers who they think they will get most money out of. I understand Spanish so I was shocked to hear people come up and to be told no problem. Anyways we went and spent our hard earned money in a nearby Italian restaurant and we were happy to give it to them rather than this restaurant. Avoid if you slightly “look” like you don’t have money.

I had two tapas, desert and a beer and paid €30. Not too expensive, but not cheap either. If you are looking for a proper tapas bar where local people go, then this is an option in the Atocha area.

The place itself is really small, do not expect any comfort: you seat on stools either directly at the bar counter or backed on a tiny board facing the wall. It gets claustrophobic with more than 10 patrons inside. I found the ambiance in the late evening quite bohemian, mostly young people enjoying rather loud pop and rock music. The food tasted great. The mini-hamburgers and squid croquettes were exquisite. The glass of house wine tasted pretty well. The service was extremely friendly and efficient. Prices were moderate considering the quality and the average prices in Madrid.

review_preview: First off, this little side street, Marques de Toca, is almost all the way down Calle de Atocha, so don't give up!  Second, they aren't open all that much (lunch on the weekends, evenings only weekdays, and closed Monday), which is a good thing, because...
review_full: First off, this little side street, Marques de Toca, is almost all the way down Calle de Atocha, so don't give up! Second, they aren't open all that much (lunch on the weekends, evenings only weekdays, and closed Monday), which is a good thing, because when they ARE, Marta is absolutely swamped with showing EVERYONE personal, super friendly, helpful attention. The chef is amazing (and fast!). I had that stunning caprese, and the langostines in tall puff-pastry "caps" (wound around them, each probably 10 inches long -- hard to describe, but amazing presentation -- in a tall glass -- and taste). Together it was a fantastic meal. The mozzarella in the caprese is called stracciatella, but is burrata -- the first time I've gotten to have that sensational experience. The heirloom tomatoes are chopped into chunks and are so dark-skinned they look like plums. The ball of cheese is in the middle, topped by fresh basil threads and a blob of pesto as well (or was that a truffled something or other?). The presentation was in a large bowl/plate with wide rim. What looked like black sesame seeds scattered around the rim was actually black salt. Very cool. Those tomatoes of course were just to die for -- after eating tons of jamon, and shrimp, and boquerones and Spanish tortilla.... fresh tomatoes were everything I was craving. They had a blackboard list of maybe 15 creative dishes, no "typical" tapas -- well, they did offer "fish and chips" (not a typical tapa anyway!), but I was assured it was not the normal dish. Had two glasses of a new red wine for me -- 100% Mencia grapes. Another winner.

title_review: Creative cooking, excellent wine, great service - highly recommended
review_preview: Our party of 5 recently went to Clos Madrid and our experience was totally in line with other reviews here.  Whilst situated in an unremarkable building, the Clos dinning room is very tastefully appointed with a lot of space between tables and a good view...
review_full: Our party of 5 recently went to Clos Madrid and our experience was totally in line with other reviews here. Whilst situated in an unremarkable building, the Clos dinning room is very tastefully appointed with a lot of space between tables and a good view of the kitchen. We had the 7 course tasting menu which was excellent with some innovative touches such as the egg yolk cooked from the inside.  Service was impeccable and non-Spanish speakers will get a full explanation of the dishes from Xavier whose English is very good. This is also a restaurant that is serious about its wine which is apparent from the wall-to-wall Zalto glassware. Excellent wine list, knowledgeably explained and, for those used to London mark-ups, the price is a very pleasant surprise too... All in all Clos feels like a well-established fine dining spot (rather than somewhere that has been open for less than 6 months). Highly recommended.

It really is amazing, and the deeper you dig, the better it gets Soft-shelled crabs were a revelation, as was an excellent plate of flank steak (beautifully dressed). A plate of Iberico ham made me realise how average my ham experiences have been to date Absolutely faultless meal, and again, I would never have gone there had it not been reviewed here.

The highlight was 'crabs on the beach', small deep fried crabs you could eat whole on an edible sandy beach. The waitress kept trying to press a tomato and mozzarella salad on us until I told her my son didn't like cheese (it looked perfectly nice and we might have ordered it if we were on our own). Quirky and fun but try and eat in the main bar, more atmosphere.

review_preview: I haven't bothered to write on Trip Advisor in a long time, but this restaurant deserves a shout-out. Clos was a pleasant surprise for us. The entire staff was warm and friendly, yet gave a formal, elegant service at the same time. The food was...
review_full: I haven't bothered to write on Trip Advisor in a long time, but this restaurant deserves a shout-out. Clos was a pleasant surprise for us. The entire staff was warm and friendly, yet gave a formal, elegant service at the same time. The food was creative, beautifully plated, and very tasty. The portions are very small and the meals are expensive -- lunch was about 50 euros for a 3-course meal or 70/75 euros for a multi-course tasting menu, so it's not an every-day place, but it's certainly worth visiting now and then to see what's new in the food world and to have a special experience. They did bring out a few tapas gratis, which was a nice touch. Bonus -- many people on the staff spoke English very well.

We had the Ensalada caprese con straciatella which my husband and I split and was really tasty. The place is quaint and finding table may be difficult, but we sat at the bar and enjoyed a beer while waiting on the salad. The staff was pleasant and attentive and provide us with a lovely basket of bread to accompany the salad. If you are a fan of caprese, I do recommend this place.

review_preview: Constant Companion and I read about La Berenjena on Tripadvisor two years ago, but did not make it there during that holiday. Last year we went there but the kitchen was closing for the afternoon so we just had drinks. Fortunately, our attempt this year...
review_full: Constant Companion and I read about La Berenjena on Tripadvisor two years ago, but did not make it there during that holiday. Last year we went there but the kitchen was closing for the afternoon so we just had drinks. Fortunately, our attempt this year was on a Thursday when they are open till 17:00.  La Berenjena is not far from the Reina Sofia or Plaza Mayor. It is on a side street off Calle de Atocha. If you were just walking by you would probably never stop. It is very small and very unpretentious! BUT, once you experience the hospitality of the staff, taste the quality of their food, behold their creative presentations, and enter into discussions with the locals whose favorite it is you will return here year after year. In fact, it is a "destination place"! Constant Companion and I had not reserved a table(there is one or two in the back) so we sat at the bar and perused the chalkboards. One was dedicated to drinks, the other to food. I suspected we were in for a treat when we were brought a tapas of Potatoes and Padron Peppers-one of my favorites! We knew before we arrived that we were going to split a Caprese Salad with Stracciatella(14 Euros)since it is one of the dishes for which they are famous. It was absolutely fabulous! CC opted for Berenjenas con Salsa de Miso (8,5 Euros). You have to look at our picture of this entree. She often cooks with Miso and adored this dish! I decided to select the Navajas de la Ria con Crema de Coco, Lima y Cilantro (15,5 Euros). OMG, razor clams with cream of coconut, lime and chilantro-just heavenly!! CC ordered two Mi Mama Me Mima Albarino @ 3,5 Euros apiece, which were a very nice accompaniment. I went with two Vina Pomal Crianza @ 3,0 Euros each. Later, we got talking with the bar tender, a couple of local guys, and a lovely young Spanish couple so we ended up there over 3 hours. La Berenjena is a local favorite and will be on our repeat list next trip to Madrid!

review_full: This place has delicious food in a very unassuming locale on a side street off the Calle de Atocha. The front of the place is a bar, but there are two tables in the back (reservations highly recommended!) and the food is truly delicious. We enjoyed their riff on a caprese salad, their razor clams, their eggplant, and their beef. Fine wine selection as well. The menu is all in Spanish, but the staff is knowledgeable, courteous, exceptionally helpful. Do not miss this place when you are in Madrid.

review_preview: We have eaten here twice in a few months and love this place. Its very innovative, reasonable cost and the food is great.Its located close to Atocha/Reina Sophia on a side street and is basically a bar and looks nothing like a restaurant from...
review_full: We have eaten here twice in a few months and love this place. Its very innovative, reasonable cost and the food is great. Its located close to Atocha/Reina Sophia on a side street and is basically a bar and looks nothing like a restaurant from the street or even looking in. It has a table for 2 and a table for 4 in the very back next to the kitchen so unless you reserve a table ahead of time you can order the food standing or on a stool in the bar area. But we noticed the Bar area can get very busy also. The Caprese salad is very good and have ordered it a few times. The baby crab is also great, kinda like eating softshell crab. The Eggplant was perfectly cooked but had a little too much miso sauce.  We have tried 2 of the skirt steak dishes and while the flavor was great they were both a little tough, but most beef in Spain is. Service is great. The house red wine was also good for the price.

review_preview: We were here for a late lunch, following the advice of a Spanish friend. The place itself is very small and they only have a couple of proper tables but you can sit on stools. We had a total of 4 glasses of wine -...
review_full: We were here for a late lunch, following the advice of a Spanish friend. The place itself is very small and they only have a couple of proper tables but you can sit on stools. We had a total of 4 glasses of wine - which was exceptional - a shared caprese salad, one main each and a dessert and the bill came to 60€ total. It's not cheap but you would pay much more on a more formal/famous restaurant for the same food. We really liked the food, it's not Spanish traditional but more like fusion, nice mix of flavours and top quality products. Service was friendly but very knowledgeable and helpful. Overall we really liked it and it was a treat, a nice way to try something new. It's definitely recommended, I think it's good also for dinner but try to book a place early. I think you won't be disappointed but it all depends on your expectations, we had high hopes but knew a bit about the place.

review_preview: We were looking for a spot to have Paella or a similar rice dish in Madrid and found this place on TripAdvisor. We loved everything we had. We started with the croqueta trio and cheese starters which were both fantastic. We ordered the Arroz Mixto...
review_full: We were looking for a spot to have Paella or a similar rice dish in Madrid and found this place on TripAdvisor. We loved everything we had. We started with the croqueta trio and cheese starters which were both fantastic. We ordered the Arroz Mixto with pork, chicken, mussels and calamari which was delicious. The rice was moist with amazing flavor and the meats were very tasty. The rice dishes are their specialties and you could tell by looking at some of the other paellas or black rice dishes some of our neighbors had. The decor of the place was very pretty which we preferred over an overly touristy paella spot (which there are a few around the city). Pick Marina Ventura if you're looking for a great Paella while in Madrid!

review_preview: We weren't expecting to eat out tonight, but life happened. A quick look at Trip Advisor for eateries in our neighbourhood revelled La Berenjena. Arrived at almost 10 on a Sunday night, with no reservation. Both (all two) tables were booked, so we ate at...
review_full: We weren't expecting to eat out tonight, but life happened. A quick look at Trip Advisor for eateries in our neighbourhood revelled La Berenjena. Arrived at almost 10 on a Sunday night, with no reservation. Both (all two) tables were booked, so we ate at the narrow little wall shelf opposite the bar. The bar and waitstaff are fantastic, and with broken English and sign language the menu was vaguely understood, and orders placed. Top of the menu is the "famous" house salad. Famous for good reason. No explanations here - try it. Rilette was wonderful, and a dish of chopped, flash cooked, salt sprinkled, smoky (subtlety anchovy infused?) fillet steak fleshed out a solid meal for two. Great wine recommendation, fabulous playlist (including Midnight Oil for a bit of Oz feel-right-at-homeness), local buzz even at that hour, all added up to a memorable meal.

title_review: Food to die for, great atmosphere.
review_preview: In October 2014, I had hoped to visit this restaurant with a friend, but she missed her plane!  On my own in Madrid for a day, I decided that eating out as a single woman was not going to  deter me from visiting the restaurants...
review_full: In October 2014, I had hoped to visit this restaurant with a friend, but she missed her plane! On my own in Madrid for a day, I decided that eating out as a single woman was not going to deter me from visiting the restaurants I wanted to try. So I stopped in on the way back to my guest house from the Reina Sofia (which is close by), and I'm so glad I did. It was the best meal I had in Madrid! My Spanish is basic, and there was a young woman there---still not sure if she was an employee or friend---who wanted to practice her English. So she asked me what I liked, and suggested several dishes. I prefer not to eat meat, so we picked seafood and vegetarian entrees. The first course was that wonderful caprese salad that seems to be very popular---and for good reason. The many pictures here show how delicious it looks and tastes. What dark, flavorful tomatoes, creamy cheese! The black salt scattered around the plate is a nice touch. I savored every bite! I wasn't sure what my next course would turn out to be, since the young lady wasn't sure what it was in English. But it was the razor clams in a lovely broth. There were 6 of them, and I savored each one as well. I had a tinto de verano to drink, and sat at the bar. It was almost empty when I came in, but as it got later, the small room got very crowded, and everyone was busy. I'm glad I was able to talk to them before the crowds came, otherwise, I know I would have felt rushed, and they wouldn't have been able to give me as much attention. I was at ease sitting at the bar---though the backless wooden stools are not conducive to really relaxing---and enjoyed people watching. There seemed to be more locals of all ages than tourists. In the background was a killer soundtrack of American music, everything from Prince to vintage Elvis. I just took a deep breath, looked around, and realized that I was having a great time. The meal was not cheap---about 26 euros---and could have been a lot more if I had had dessert or tried some other dishes. But I felt it was worth the price for such delicious, innovative food (I saw other interesting looking dishes coming out of the kitchen), and appealing atmosphere. I'd love to go back!

review_full: We made a reservation for 9pm through Trip Advisor and glad we did, they had people waiting we when arrived but we sat right down. As with most restaurants in Spain this place is small so they use the sidewalk for additional space. Our server’s name was Luigi and he was amazing, using as much English as possible to help us through picking some specialties. We chose a bottle of Chianti and the dinner for 2. We started with the baked provolone and it did not disappoint, that pan left the table scraped clean. My wife had the tagliatelle bolognese, she loved the flavor and al dente pasta, I tried a bite and it was super yummy. I had the pizza favorita which was a veggie option with mushrooms and eggplant. I think it’s in the top 5 pizzas I have ever eaten, super thin and crispy crust. We had the strawberry creme dessert to top off our night. Everything was delicious but the real draw is the location, staff, and ambiance this restaurant provides.

title_review: Some of the best Italian I have ever had!
review_preview: We picked Trattoria Malatesta the other night because it was close to our hotel - we were tired travelers - and the place had a good Tripadvisor rating. We were so happy we did! I think we got the last open table at 9 PM....
review_full: We picked Trattoria Malatesta the other night because it was close to our hotel - we were tired travelers - and the place had a good Tripadvisor rating. We were so happy we did! I think we got the last open table at 9 PM. It was cozy on a very cold night in Madrid. My partner had picked two things from the menu, a roast beef appetizer and a main course (oxtail) and both dishes were sold out. I was worried she wouldn't enjoy herself because she was so disappointed. So she went with second choices, a vegetable strata, and lasagne. I had a seafood ravioli. They were all exquisite, beautifully blended flavors and delicately made. And a wonderful light cheesecake for dessert. This truly was one of the nicest Italian meals I have ever had - and that includes some pretty great places in Rome and Tuscany last year. The place had that "made with love" feel that transforms you into a happy camper by the end of the meal. Go!

review_preview: If you're looking for a break from Spanish food and want something Italian - this is the place to be! We ordered 4 varieties of pasta - tagliatelle funghi misti, taliolini pesto, pappardelle (or tagliatelle?) with mussels/clams, and another vegetarian style pasta.  Everything was fresh,...
review_full: If you're looking for a break from Spanish food and want something Italian - this is the place to be!  We ordered 4 varieties of pasta - tagliatelle funghi misti, taliolini pesto, pappardelle (or tagliatelle?) with mussels/clams, and another vegetarian style pasta. Everything was fresh, light, made in-house, and absolutely excellent. The complex flavor of the sauces in combination with the handmade pasta rival anything I've had in Italy - and probably one of my favorite Italian places of all time (all countries considered).  Tiramisu was great as well - though not the best I've had in my travels.  The service was very friendly and we felt very welcomed here - unlike many other Spanish establishments we went to during our trip. We barely spoke any Spanish/italian but the server did his best in answering our questions in English - he even took out and showed us plates of different pasta noodles when we had a question about the menu. The serving is on the small side (though comparable to the serving sizes in Italy as well..) which leaves you wanting something more.

review_preview: I booked here after having read the other reviews on Trip Advisor and wasn't disappointed. The place itself is in a very quaint pedestrianised street in a busy part of the city. The restaurant has a terrace, an upstairs and a downstairs - careful when...
review_full: I booked here after having read the other reviews on Trip Advisor and wasn't disappointed. The place itself is in a very quaint pedestrianised street in a busy part of the city. The restaurant has a terrace, an upstairs and a downstairs - careful when wearing high heels and needing to go downstairs either to the bathroom or if you are seated there, the stairs are lethal! I had booked a table for three and originally were given a table downstairs but the waiters were able to accommodate us as it was such a lovely evening and gave us a table on the terrace. The menu is ample so there is a very wide choice of food. Starters/salads cost approximately 8-11 euros. We shared the provoletta (grilled cheese) and a mini lasagne style dish made up of layers of aubergine, both of which were divine. For your main course, there are pastas, pizzas, risottos, meat... enough for everyone. I'm a vegetarian and normally have a problem finding things on the menu but i was spoilt for choice. I chose the ravioli stuffed with spinach & cheese accompanied with a wild mushroom sauce, a friend had a spicy pizza and another had the wild mushroom risotto. Each main course ranged from 10 - 15 euros, and they were all individually delicious. the desserts cost about 5 euros. We had the canoli with berry sauce (heaven) and a kind of crumble with cream, and to drink 2 bottles of the rosé Lambrussco (very easy on the palate!). The whole meal cost 33 euros each. There was an offer for 2 people to share a starter plus two main courses at 18 euros, not including the drink. The food might seem a little pricey but it really is delicious and the ambience is wonderful if you are sat outside on the terrace. The waiters were friendly but took quite a long time coming to take our order and giving us our bill at the end. Having said that, all in all it was a very good experience.

title_review: This is the place for Italian in Madrid
review_preview: We sat outside in a nice small alleyway, with some pedestrian traffic, but it was never bothersome.  Beautiful atmosphere both outdoors and inside- the lower level floor had a nice brick-interior Italian type decor.We ordered Tagliatelle, Lasagna, and Spaghetti- and they were all spectacular....
review_full: We sat outside in a nice small alleyway, with some pedestrian traffic, but it was never bothersome. Beautiful atmosphere both outdoors and inside- the lower level floor had a nice brick-interior Italian type decor. We ordered Tagliatelle, Lasagna, and Spaghetti- and they were all spectacular. For desert, the Torta Caprese con gelato di cannella was the best desert that I have had this year- and I do my share of desert-tasting across Europe! One important note- the full dinner menu was available after 7 PM. We were only given a pizza menu when we sat down at 10 minutes before 7, but then the waiter let us in on the fact that the full menu would be available after 7. Their website (http://trattoriamalatesta.com/) is very helpful if you want to see photos and the menu.

Throughout our whole meal, the waiters kept passing by and pushing us to get passed which made it very difficult to eat and have a conversation. We didn't co plain about this as we understood the place was busy. However, when we asked for the bill we noticed there were several mistakes. First of all, we were charged for three drinks although we had only had too. Secondly, we'd ordered a half portion but were charged a full portion. And after having the bill corrected twice, there was still a mistake: the half portion was billed 3 euros more than it should have been. By then, we were tired of having to asked them to correct the bill again so we just paid and left. I'm pretty sure this wasn't a mistake and was voluntary but the waitress just kept on smiling and apologizing for the mistakes. In any case, I think that when there is a mistake once, the bill should be corrected immediately and should be correct the second time. We had to ask three times to get it almost right!

Dessert were fantastic and the Cafe Americano with hot milk was the best we have had in Madrid. A lovely complimentary glass of Limoncello was served as well before our dessert. Our waiter, Mario, was attentive and excellent. I would highly recommend this restaurant.

Appetisers and dishes all exceed expectations. We have been 6 times which says it all. The place was full last night, and the buzz amongst customers creates a very relaxed atmosphere. Every dish is explained in English, Spanish and some Italian! My wife is vegetarian and the team always rise to the challenge with ease and seem to enjoy creating dishes from fantastic ingredients. See the photos attached for the innovative gastronomic creations.  The staff are highly trained and love working there...you can tell from the way they talk and interact with each other and customers. This restaurant is a must visit. Go soon whilst you still can...it will become a destination taberna for locals and travellers alike.

review_preview: Trip Advisor does it again. What a great find. On arriving we were concerned we'd turned up at a corner café with a beer and baguette on the menu - how wrong we were. The waiters, chefs, everyone at the restaurant were great. There is...
review_full: Trip Advisor does it again. What a great find. On arriving we were concerned we'd turned up at a corner café with a beer and baguette on the menu - how wrong we were. The waiters, chefs, everyone at the restaurant were great. There is something so cool about Spain, when you can have an excellent top quality meal, served by knowledgeable waiters and competent chefs who are casually dressed under their uniforms - it is totally relaxing. We were offered a taster menu and seven courses later we were still amazed by how good each course had been. Each dish was served with an explanation including an award winning course that included fresh puree chorizo and squid. I want to go back to this restaurant and try every single item on their menu - it's absolutely excellent.

It's a family business and the waiters are amazingly attentive. Particularly loved the little cart they wheel over to your table to make their Gin and Tonic cocktails. It's like a little theatre piece! 7 course taster menu was fab and they checked if there was anything we didn't like before they brought everything out, so they could substitute where required. Also, if you have children, the staff were so sweet to all the kids in the restaurant and went out of their way to make them feel special. All in all, fantastic!

The wine selection is limited but good. However the atmosphere is pure fun, geat service (as long as you can shout loudly over everyone else, and the prices are great for the quality of the food. The bar tender must have liked us since he offered us dessert wine and wouldn't stop pouring until we begged him no mas.

There are two or three tables in a very confined space, and the chairs are really stools with no backs, not very conducive to dining. The food was ok, fine but nothing special. I won't bother to talk about what we ate because I wouldn't put this place on my recommend list. Service was pretty good. Here's the other "mistake" we made. Casa Lucas is across the street from Casa Lucio, and we mistakenly stopped in there first, thinking that was our restaurant. I can't vouch for the food because we didn't get to eat there, but Casa Lucio appears to be fine dining, beautiful, probably expensive, must have a reservation. We would have preferred to eat there. The worst part was that when we spoke to the maitre'd there and cleared up the confusion about the name, he informed us that the two places have the same owner but indicated that Casa Lucas is not a "restaurant". He was certainly right.

title_review: Such a good experience, we came back a second time!
review_preview: Casa Lucas is right around the corner from where we stayed in Madrid, and we happened to eat there our first night. As I said, we enjoyed it so much, we ended up coming back for our last night in Madrid. First time, we were...
review_full: Casa Lucas is right around the corner from where we stayed in Madrid, and we happened to eat there our first night. As I said, we enjoyed it so much, we ended up coming back for our last night in Madrid. First time, we were there a little early (jet lagged from our flight to Spain) and we were able to get a table. Second time, the place was packed, however we were able to get stools at the bar. Over the 2 visits, we had the Madrid (blood sausage i.e., “morcilla”, egg, tomato confit on bread), ham croquettes, tataki (tuna with onion and soy sauce over apple sauce), the calamari (a massive plate of calamari wrapped in bacon and tossed in squid ink) and a puff pastry with more morcilla. (The waiter warned us the second time around that we were ordering a lot of food - he was right - very generous portions.) I thought that the service was great, the atmosphere was friendly, and the food was very good.

review_preview: This restaurant is small so my first piece of advice is to book. The menu is interesting with plenty choices. We had the squid and prawn starter and the fried green tomatoes- both were fabulous- really large portions. Many guests seemed to order  a starter...
review_full: This restaurant is small so my first piece of advice is to book. The menu is interesting with plenty choices. We had the squid and prawn starter and the fried green tomatoes- both were fabulous- really large portions. Many guests seemed to order a starter to share which is plenty and leaves more room for the main course. Main course for me was octopus with guacamole - THE BEST MAINCOURSE EVER!!! It was succulent inside and roasted on outside, served with lovely guacamole and fabulous potatoe that I couldn't even begin to describe- you just have to taste it! We also had. Cod which was really good and I was tempted by the yellow fin tuna dish on the menu so I will just have to visit again. We ordered a bottle of Merlot which was about €20 and it was lovely, rich deep colour and flavour. Starters are approx €7 and mains €12 - €16: Fantastic food, reasonable prices and excellent enthusiastic staff. Couldn't recommend this restaurant more highly, it's a real little gem!

title_review: Great food served with a smile
review_preview: Having eaten out for the three days we have been in Madrid so far, this is the first place we've eaten that has provided a truly welcoming experience and service with the smile.  And the food just happens to be terrific.We arrived around 9pm...
review_full: Having eaten out for the three days we have been in Madrid so far, this is the first place we've eaten that has provided a truly welcoming experience and service with the smile. And the food just happens to be terrific. We arrived around 9pm and the place was already packed but with no others waiting. This place was small like most of the other places on this street. We were attended to quickly but were kindly told that a table would take about 40 minutes so we pulled up a tiny corner and the people next to us graciously relented a little wiggle room so that my wife and our 16month old (yes we're adventurous :) could get a little more comfy. The server, while playfully greeting our daughter, offered to make even more room for us by tucking our stroller away in a storage closet. This tone of helpful, attentive, and friendly service carried on throughout our experience here with all of the staff. The English menu we were given helped a little but wasn't really needed as Maria on their staff did speak English well. She helped my wife pick a nice fruity glass of white wine and we ordered the calamari and the risotto with foie gras. The calamari came out looking like perfect golden breaded strips wrapped in crisp ham. On the same plate were a kind of squid ink mousse. The staff cut up the calamari and ham into smaller portions and mixed the squid ink in with it in front of us. The result was a heavenly mix of the most lightly textured, not at all rubbery, calamari we've ever had along with a crispy outside and the rich flavor of squid ink bringing it all together. This was a large portion and if we were truly hungry my wife and I could have easily finished it because it was that good. The risotto came out in good pace as a foie gras patty and a fried egg floating in a bed of rice. This too was cut up and mixed together for us. I am a foie gras fan but the flavor of this dish is very strong. It is a good strong, but was an unexpected one. Overall the dish was still very delicious and as it also came out in a large serving which we could not finish it either. So note that you may easily over order here. Having a toddler we couldn't eat too fast but we never felt rushed. The bill was very reasonable for the quality and quantity of food, two drinks, and service. On our way out the staff helped carry out to the sidewalk and waved good night to us. This place definitely deserves its awards. We are planning on coming back to try out other dishes. I would recommend this to anyone especially families.

review_preview: Very little place in a neat neighborhood.  Reasonable prices and truly excellent food.  The key here is getting in.  They restaurant seats probably not more than 20 people.  We went on a whim and got a spot.  Several groups were turned away—there was just no...
review_full: Very little place in a neat neighborhood. Reasonable prices and truly excellent food. The key here is getting in. They restaurant seats probably not more than 20 people. We went on a whim and got a spot. Several groups were turned away—there was just no room. If you know your schedule, try to book ahead. Otherwise, it’s a neighborhood with many restaurants, so you can try your luck and go somewhere else if you can’t get a seat.  Portions are very large. We noticed others sharing, so we got one toast (delicious pork on a toast) and one main (cous cous con pollo with curried veggies) to share and it was more than enough food. The free app was a very tasty salami. Everything we had at Casa Lucas was delicious!

review_preview: My husband and I lunched here today after a trip to Toledo. The restaurant is small but the tapas were great and the staff was great. Our first waiter spoke perfect English and is Spanish by way of Venezuela and Boca Raton, FL., and helped...
review_full: My husband and I lunched here today after a trip to Toledo. The restaurant is small but the tapas were great and the staff was great. Our first waiter spoke perfect English and is Spanish by way of Venezuela and Boca Raton, FL., and helped us order our food. Our other waiter is Spanish but loves CA and "The Boss". As a Jersey girl I had to agree. He introduced me to new and delicious red wine. But to the food! First a combo plate of half ham and half mushroom croquettes... I do not know the cheese they use... but they are to die for. Then grilled pork on caramelized onions on some fabulous peasant bread.... yum.... then risotto with foie gras and a poached egg, which they mix into the risotto at your table. Nirvana.  It was fabulous and filled with locals; but they could not have been nicer. Totally worth the trip!

review_preview: I attended a conference in Madrid recently, and whist there has the occasion to dine at BAHIA TABERNA a small restaurant out near the Madrid Airport. I ate there twice, once in the small restaurant at the back of the building and the second time...
review_full: I attended a conference in Madrid recently, and whist there has the occasion to dine at BAHIA TABERNA a small restaurant out near the Madrid Airport. I ate there twice, once in the small restaurant at the back of the building and the second time in the bar area (with post-prandials taken outside).  The Bahia Taberna is a small place located in a residential area. From the outside it looks just like countless other places throughout span (and the world). But step inside, and things change. In the back, there are a few tables (maybe a dozen or so covers) along with the Pass into the kitchen. You get a nice view of the workings sitting here. The front is more of a bar with tall chair. And of course, being Spain, you can eat and drink outside. The menus is mainly Mediterranean and the service sort of tapas style, reminisicnt of the tasting menus I’ve had at other places. On the first night we had several dishes (five courses I think) - the octopus was especially good and the chicken sublime. But the cheesecake for dessert was to die for! We had seconds of that on my first visit and I insisted we have it on our second. A good choice both times.  Drinks were good - the first time we had a nice abraninio and a Ribera del Duero while the second visit I drank wine from the glass (the ‘house’ RBD) as the others were on beer or coke. Their signature drink here seems to be Gin And Tonic. Nothing very special, I hear you say - yeah, right! Possibly the best G&Ts I’ve had in decades. Worth visiting for the drink alone! While the food and drink was fantastic, the service was even better. The manager and staff were all very passionate about their food and their place and went out of their way to make us feel happy and welcome. They were very informal (tshirts/short trousers), relaxed but very good at delivering an outstanding experience. It’s no wonder why this place is ranked #3 in Madrid! All things combined, both visits were outstanding - albeit different in ambience (the more formal restaurant vs the bar). This is the sort of place that would get me to go back again and again. I can’t wait to return.

review_preview: Bahia is off the beaten track, near the airport.  My wife and I used Trip Advisor to find a great restaurant for our last night in Madrid and are still talking about it.  Great advice fromTrip Advisor, we arrived early for our 8 pm reservations...
review_full: Bahia is off the beaten track, near the airport. My wife and I used Trip Advisor to find a great restaurant for our last night in Madrid and are still talking about it. Great advice fromTrip Advisor, we arrived early for our 8 pm reservations and realized they don't really open till 8:30, but we sat in the outside bar and had excellent drinks. They were prepared at the table too, very nice. We were introduced to Miguel who spoke excellent English who was to become our waiter. When our table was ready he brought our drinks and seated us. Very small restaurant but they have seating in the bar, not as cosy but it would work. Miguel showed us the small menu and asked if we would like him to choose for us. He also asked if we have any allergies to any food! Nice touch. We then proceeded to be treated to probably one of the most pleasant dining experiences we've ever had. 4 courses, each served on different types of plates, and fresh silverware with each course. Miguel checked with us often, even one of the owners/managers checked to see if everything was good. And the food, the flavors, presentation, every course was fantastic! I could keep going on, just go. And did I mention they offered to call me a taxi without my asking for one? It was waiting for us when we we finished. Don't bother trying to find someplace closer, go, just go.

title_review: Food is good, but service is 5 star
review_preview: We arrived at Casa Lucas a little past 8pm. We were trying to eat early as we are packing to go back to the States.  Of all of the restuarants we have visited in Madrid and Barcelona, this is by far the friendliest we have...
review_full: We arrived at Casa Lucas a little past 8pm. We were trying to eat early as we are packing to go back to the States. Of all of the restuarants we have visited in Madrid and Barcelona, this is by far the friendliest we have encountered in our week in Spain. Maria was very tolerant of our attempt at Spanish and also laughed with us and provided great recommendations for dinner and wine. The rest of the staff was also very friendly and didn't make us feel unwelcome in their establishment It is sad to say that in several restaurants in Spain, we were made to feel we were not welcome. This was not the case at Casa Lucas.  The building is very quaint and has just the right ambience for a late supper.  It is true, their roasted meat was delicious. We had chicken, pork and tuna. We also had a goat cheese salad that was wonderful.  I highly recommend Casa Lucas. It is very deserving of its ranking on TripAdvisor.

If you get the chance you should try the Alicante Casa de Abuelo. I would happily have eaten here for every meal.

title_review: who'da thunk there was good italian in the Plaza Mayor?
review_preview: This place was an accidental find.  We were looking for anything BUT tapas and were drawn in by the smell of pizza cooking in the oven.  There were actually Italians working here and I got to practice my Italian!  The food was great.  We could...
review_full: This place was an accidental find. We were looking for anything BUT tapas and were drawn in by the smell of pizza cooking in the oven. There were actually Italians working here and I got to practice my Italian! The food was great. We could not eat outside so instead ate in the cave (basement). That was a pleasant surprise: cool, quiet, cozy. The pizzas were delicious. The crust could stand on its own (well seasoned). The gorganzola croquettes were fantastic. The carpaccio was okay; I did not find it that flavorful. The orange/mozzarella and insalata caprese salads were very good. The spaghetti carbonara was very good as well. They had a drink called a "tinto de verano" which was somewhat like a sangria but lighter...excellent (and cheap!). The strawberry napoleon was very good. The tiramisu was nice (not too sweet) but the panna cotta was way too sweet. As it is right across the street from the Chocolateria San Gines, you could just as well go there...if you had the room.

title_review: Good food, but not for a romantic dinner
review_preview: Casa Lucas has received great reviews on numerous of Review sites (Yelp, 11870, Tripadvisor) and I totally see why; Good quality food, authentic and attentive staff, medium priced and good location. We ate the third and last "Hot tapas" dish on the menu consisting of...
review_full: Casa Lucas has received great reviews on numerous of Review sites (Yelp, 11870, Tripadvisor) and I totally see why; Good quality food, authentic and attentive staff, medium priced and good location. We ate the third and last "Hot tapas" dish on the menu consisting of pan-fried chicken breast on a bed of caramelised red onion shavings served on a piece of fresh white loaf. The whole tapa was topped with a yellow pure (do not know the ingredients), however, it reminded me of a root vegetable pure with sweet tones. The second course out was a tomato, basil and goat cheese salad generously sprinkled with a tasty and sharp-coloured olive oil (could have added a few sea salt flakes to send me "off the top"). Thirdly, we were served a black good portioned caneloni filled vegetables (carrots) and gambas placed in a thick (and delicious) sauce of cream, seafood stock and poppy seeds (WOW!). The only big, big minus was that the place is small and too popular for its own good.. Meaning the tables in which initially are meant for four are filled-up with five-six-seven making the path line to kitchen/bar for the waiting staff a walking nightmare (and the guests are bumped in the back a few times..). The restaurant does not have desserts. Do not know if it is because they simple do what they can best (the excellent food) or, again; want people to leave once they have eaten to increase the table turnover. Regardless of this; the waiting staff are friendly, experienced and quick. I would recommend the place for a (small) group of friends (not couple) who wants a dinner before hitting the city OR come between 19-21.00 and you will be enjoying the dinner for a longer period. Good luck!

title_review: Absolutely Delicious. A New Must Visit
review_preview: What a great find -- and somewhere that I've walked by many times given its central location and proximity to the Plaza Mayor.The food is wonderful and beautifully presented. Frankly everyone in the restaurant was raving about what they were eating and sharing their...
review_full: What a great find -- and somewhere that I've walked by many times given its central location and proximity to the Plaza Mayor. The food is wonderful and beautifully presented. Frankly everyone in the restaurant was raving about what they were eating and sharing their experiences with the tables around them. I had a beautiful arugula salad and a pizza. As good as anywhere. Obviously a lot of care goes into their preparation. The service is outstanding, all staff seem to speak perfectly fluent English and enjoy engaging with their guests of all nationalities -- last night there were Germans, Spanish, Israelis and of course Americans. Sometimes you just can't take another meal of tapas. Trattoria Malatesta is an outstanding alternative (and now one of my favorite restaurants in Madrid).

Something about prices: Pan de las casa (bread you get when you are getting seated: fixed price of 1,30 euro per person), reasonable priced wine list (we got a delicious red wine for only 15 euro a bottle), tagliatelle della casa 14,5 euro, ...  Next time we visit Madrid, we'll come back to try other specialties!

We were charged for 2 servings of bread when we didn't even have one, but the wait staff was more than willing to correct the error. Also be warned that the bathrooms are coed which took me by surprise. Suggest you make reservations ahead since it gets packed fairly fast at dinner time. Enjoy!

title_review: Some of the Best Tapas Around
review_preview: If you're going to brave the Calle Cava Baja street in the Latin district, don't be discouraged if you're not used to small eateries with few tables and big crowds. Keep at it until you find someone in the place who can tell you how...
review_full: If you're going to brave the Calle Cava Baja street in the Latin district, don't be discouraged if you're not used to small eateries with few tables and big crowds. Keep at it until you find someone in the place who can tell you how long for a table, and unless you're desparately hungry, wait it out. Most of the crowds are not there to sit down and eat, they are there to stand, have a quick tapa and a glass of wine or a beer, and socialize with friends. It may not be as long as you think for a table. As far as Casa Lucas, we tried 5 places in the Latin district, 4 of them on Calle Cava Baja. Of them all, Casa Lucas was our favorite. We had a risotto, a potato dish and the most amazing shredded meat dish that I could have had for 5 nights straight. Absolutely amazing food, we talked about that meat dish the entire way back to our hotel. I recommend you do what we did, which is ask the staff for their recommendations. They abosultely nailed it. It's small, crowded, and noisy. Perfect!!!

The quality price relation is outstanding, the local atmosphere is wonderful and the location could bee better. I really reccomend that place!

title_review: Solid Italian and good pizza in Madrid
review_preview: As my wife is from Madrid, we come to this fantastic city at least twice a year. We usually go for Spanish food, however this time we were browsing for good restaurants in Madrid and Trattoria Maltesta showed up really high in the most recent...
review_full: As my wife is from Madrid, we come to this fantastic city at least twice a year. We usually go for Spanish food, however this time we were browsing for good restaurants in Madrid and Trattoria Maltesta showed up really high in the most recent Trip Advisor ranking, so we decided to give it a go. The atmosphere is nice and the food is good. We had some antipasto and then a pizza (bufala and nostra), they were both very good. We also had a nice millefoglie for dessert. Overall, very convincing and solid. The only thing I thought they could perhaps improve is service: a little stiff and impersonal, something you would not normally expect from an Italian restaurant.

title_review: Great food.  Wanted to experience more
review_preview: The trouble with eating alone in spain is that a lot of the tapas eateries are all based around sharing plates of food. Thus there was so much on the menu that i'd like to have tried but couldnt because of portion sizes and cost....
review_full: The trouble with eating alone in spain is that a lot of the tapas eateries are all based around sharing plates of food. Thus there was so much on the menu that i'd like to have tried but couldnt because of portion sizes and cost. Anyway the food; i opted for the pork loin on a bed of caramelised onions. Absolutely succulent meat and sweet onions all on top of some warm french bread. Lovely. There were only two dishes from the mains they could do as smaller dishes and i opted for the Calamari. When it came out it looked amazing but before i had a chance to tuck in the waiter had cut everything up for me and mixed it around. Taste wise it was still sublime but i'd quite liked to have done all this myself. Anyway i can see why this place does so well on trip advisor. The reviews are well deserved. If you want to try it out get there early though. I arrived on a saturday night just after 8. By the time i left at 9 the place was full plus its small, very small.

review_preview: Our expectations were high going in to Casa lucas given the number of reviews stating the food was 'mind blowing'. I think it is fair to say the place went above and beyond our expectations, and we would happily take a trip back to Madrid...
review_full: Our expectations were high going in to Casa lucas given the number of reviews stating the food was 'mind blowing'. I think it is fair to say the place went above and beyond our expectations, and we would happily take a trip back to Madrid just to dine at casa lucas again.  Selma was an incredible host, making sure we got a comfortable table and guiding us expertly on ordering the right proportion of dishes and styles (which is refreshing from the plethora of tourist traps trying to push and upsell orders). The portions were generous and filling and we would have ordered way too much food if not for her advice (not to mention 4 fantastic glasses of wine which she catered to our palate). We ordered two pintxos - the pork loin on apple sauce and blood sausage with scrambled eggs. Both we absolutely delicious. The mains were 1/2 portion each of fried squid with squid ink mousse (which was expertly cut and served by Selma) and the black pasta stuffed with sea food - very different flavours and textures, but fabulous in their own way. In conclusion, amazing food, ambience and service, was truly mind-blowing and a great change from the tourist trap of Mercado de San Miguel which we visited earlier in the day. Highly recommended, one of our best meals of the year.

title_review: Delicious paella and wine; great service
review_preview: Dined on a Saturday night around 9p. Not many patrons. Restaurant specialty is paella and they did not disappoint. We had the lobster paella with lobster claws and tail, crab, clams and mussels. This dish has more sauce to it and it is delicious. Great...
review_full: Dined on a Saturday night around 9p. Not many patrons. Restaurant specialty is paella and they did not disappoint. We had the lobster paella with lobster claws and tail, crab, clams and mussels. This dish has more sauce to it and it is delicious. Great to sop up with bread. They give you all the tools you need to enjoy every part. Almost intimidating when you see it all. Some work needed - cracking opening shells, definitely worth it. I even saw a waiter show a diner how to open and get to the meat of his crab. Waiter suggested a wine that paired perfectly with our dish. Dessert was also good. Chocolate fondue cake with orange sauce. Different take on apple tart with straw like base. Excellent meal. Location is also nice but hidden. Taxi driver needed map help. Quaint cobblestone streets. Off the main area. Very good food here. Many dishes to try. Highly recommend.

They also served a couple free tapas - bread, bean soup, and a delicious homemade chocolate at the end. Loved this place and would highly recommend!

review_preview: We have been back to La Paloma for both lunch and dinner on may occasions since our previous review of December 2015. We rate this restaurant highly and regard it as our favourite in Madrid. The dining room is elegant and stylish but yet comfortable...
review_full: We have been back to La Paloma for both lunch and dinner on may occasions since our previous review of December 2015. We rate this restaurant highly and regard it as our favourite in Madrid.  The dining room is elegant and stylish but yet comfortable and relaxing. We find the level of service to be consistently outstanding. The menu is more than sufficiently varied for us and there are always a number of "specials of the day". The chef seems to focus on using, as far as is possible, fresh local produce, to prepare it perfectly and present it professionally. The wine list is fairly extensive and has wine to suit most tastes and pockets. La Paloma is a fine dining restaurant and, therefore, not cheap but for us it offers value for money - for a three course meal with wine our typical spend is €55 to €75 per head. A nice touch is that half portions of many of the dishes can be ordered. We visit Madrid five or six times a year and try to fit in at least a couple of meals here on each visit.

title_review: Go for tapas & stay for the vermuth

review_full: Read a (+) post about a restaurant in the La Latina area to try. And, so we did. Behind an unassuming door, into the bar area (grab a spot,even if it is near the door or in the 2 movie theater seats) while you wait for a table. The dining area located in the “ basement” only seats about 16-20. For diners, there is no feeling to rush for those who are licking their chops waiting for their opportunity to dine. While you wait, ENJOY a La Concha vermuth cocktail! Friendly, local taberna. Go for the tapas and stay for the vermuth!

title_review: Master that plays with senses of taste
review_preview: No Planned my travels found a way to Madrid with 1 day to spend time . I love the Spanish Gastronomy and for the best chefs of the world are active in this country. So at the last moment I booked a table at Destage...
review_full: No Planned my travels found a way to Madrid with 1 day to spend time . I love the Spanish Gastronomy and for the best chefs of the world are active in this country. So at the last moment I booked a table at Destage . I was not aware it was there first day of reopening afther the Corrona troubles . This was not a problem this staff gave me feeling like a well organized team at the top of their skills . When you come here well next to a fine staff you fill find discoveries and a chef that puts focus to bring the maximum out of a product . Yes he takes risks but he seem to be aware of what he is doing . I took the 18 course tasting Menue and it didn t disappoint . The restaurant is open Minded and the dishes on your table will blow you mind once you beging to taste . Wine pairing at is best . For me this was 3 star level and an experience to be at the level of restaurants like Quique da costa and Abac 2 places I admire . Yes it was a discovery for me but one I did not regret and if you travel to Madrid consider this place to put in your bucket list

review_preview: I just finished touring Spain where I ate at El Cellar Con Roca, Disfrutar, Lasarte, DiverXO and here.  They are all great restaurants.  However, in Madrid my meal at Terraza Casino/Paco Roncero was significantly better than DiverXO.  The food was more memorable and the service...
review_full: I just finished touring Spain where I ate at El Cellar Con Roca, Disfrutar, Lasarte, DiverXO and here. They are all great restaurants. However, in Madrid my meal at Terraza Casino/Paco Roncero was significantly better than DiverXO. The food was more memorable and the service was perfect. Easily two michelin star quality and fun. (Unfortunately the bill at DiverXO was almost twice that of Terraa Casino because the food and wine was higher priced.) I understand that this place gets complaints because it is housed inside a private club that has a jacket requirement. I wore a jacket but half of the guests got past the club front desk without a jacket since they had winter overcoats on and once inside the club, the restaurant staff didn't care.  Overall I would recommend this place if you like molecular cuisine like at Disfrutar, Minibar or Molecular Tapas.

review_preview: I was to go there alone but didn’t find any options for 1 person table on their website, so I decided to write them. They are very efficient in replying emails, good english with a clear-cut answer.I tried to smaller version of the menu...
review_full: I was to go there alone but didn’t find any options for 1 person table on their website, so I decided to write them. They are very efficient in replying emails, good english with a clear-cut answer. I tried to smaller version of the menu (145€). Before you get seated, the first appetizer will be served with a drink at the bar in front of the restaurant.  The fried calamari was spectacular, taking into account that it was fried without any batter. Then they will proceed to the kitchen. The theme menu as of jan 2020 was about sustainability. How they tried to use all parts of seafood in their restaurants. It was fun. I myself was explained about the process by Diego, the chef owner. He was very friendly, knowledgeable and approachable. It was quite an experience.  Then they served the rest of the dishes on the table.  I was impressed by almost every dishes, especially the dessert with strawberry which is appropriately named in spanish beber con la boca llena.  My next table was a couple with a 5-6 year old kid who was very well behaved and a food enthusiast. The restaurant also managed very professionally with the kids. So if you happen to bring one along, you might consider asking them for a kid menu or something.  The service is a michelin star level. Professional, attentive but not overwhelming. I will go back !

The food and its presentation is an experience in itself - I am sure there has enough been said about this already, so  we can just confirm this is really worth it. The wine selection is Spanish centred and not too expensive comparing it with restaurants of comparable class around the globe. If you are passing trough Madrid with your family and your kids are 8years and older, do not hesitate to book, it is an experience for them to remember.

review_preview: This was my first  dining experience at the Casino- not sure why I have never  been before?- possibly my distaste for gambling at any level?- but the Chefs gastronomic menu was discussed at a recent cocktail reception and curiosity got the better of me !...
review_full: This was my first dining experience at the Casino- not sure why I have never been before?- possibly my distaste for gambling at any level?- but the Chefs gastronomic menu was discussed at a recent cocktail reception and curiosity got the better of me ! It was an amazing dining experience.  Location is wonderful- very formal. Very stylish. Very elegant. Located in a wonderful building which does not disappoint inside- beautiful chandeliers and frescos on the ceiling. Ornate plaster mouldings. It is beautiful and raises expectations for the menu for sure. Imagine then how I felt when I was presented with the Degustation menu to find that the first course was a pizza carbonara ?!!!! My heart sank !!! But you just have to go for it !!! Any concerns that I had evaporated on the first mouthful ! The chef is playful with his menu- international too- includes pizza, taco, curry and a thai dish. It some ways it seems like an experimental menu but none of the experiments went wrong ! It is a menu that gives the chefs the opportunity to show off their talents for sure. The food was beautiful in terms of the variery of dishes, the flavours and the presentation. In total there are 25 courses ( i think) and wine pairing is available- fortunately it doesnt include 25 wines otherwise you would be under the table for the second half of the meal ! Each dish is , of course, very small, and a taster but the overall impact of the meal is so very memorable. I have dined at many fine restaurants in Madrid but this is the most memorable dining experience.  Of course it is top end pricing which only reflects the qulaity of the establishment and the chefs team- also the very professional staff in front of house - the Degustation menu is €185 and wine pairings €110 but this does include IVA !! At the time of writing I do not know if this place is Michelin starred ? - it must be? Possibly a 2☆- if not Michelin are missing a trick. This place has the WOW factor ! Was there a downside ? The only downside I can think of is that we did not get a menu for the wine pairings- in some ways , my fault, I should have asked, but was too absorbed with the food menu, but it would have been better to have known what we were drinking. All of the wines were totally complimentary to the meal and for once, they were definately secondary to the food itself.

review_preview: So glad to have found this sweet little spot! Stopped in upstairs for a vermouth, then decided to venture downstairs and stay for dinner. First, the vermouth. House made and delicious. It begins with a martini glass, two ice cubes and a spritz from an...
review_full: So glad to have found this sweet little spot! Stopped in upstairs for a vermouth, then decided to venture downstairs and stay for dinner. First, the vermouth. House made and delicious. It begins with a martini glass, two ice cubes and a spritz from an atomizer. Then the vermouth is poured over the ice. Just a bit of Campari is drizzled on top, then garnished with a lemon twist and olive. Perfection! When I told my server I was celiaca, she took my menu and replaced it with a special menu for gluten free. A tapas bite of mozzarella on a GF cracker was presented with my drink. Then I enjoyed a delicious chicken curry with a side of GF bread. The food was as wonderful as the vermouth! This was truly a great find in the La Latina neighborhood.
